Content:
> is UNI purely a governance token or does it have some sort of fee sharing elements?
@TLB  

Also this

`UNI holders are responsible for ensuring that governance decisions are made in compliance with applicable laws and regulations. To help facilitate this, the fee switch has been initialized to a contract UNI holders can use to vote on tokens for which they will collect fees. The community is encouraged to consult knowledgeable legal and regulatory professionals before implementing any specific proposal.`

Author: kolten
Content: @Dream2020 here's how they found past users of Uniswap: https://github.com/Uniswap/retroactive-query

Author: Dream2020#4209
Content: @Kolten Thanks . it is statistic repo on block chain snapshot , when the result come out, how distribute such many tokens? write scripts to call UNI contract to transfer ?

Author: kolten
Content:
They created a Merkle tree of addresses, balances, etc: https://mrkl.uniswap.org/

There is a contract called MerkleDistributor.sol that allows anyone to claim pre-allocated UNI tokens if they exist in a Merkle root: https://etherscan.io/address/0x090d4613473dee047c3f2706764f49e0821d256e#code

Author: kolten
Content: That's why you have to "claim" the tokens vs just getting them dropped to your address. When you submit a tx to claim, you're submitting a proof to the distributor contract.

Author: Dream2020#4209
Content: oh, wonderful!

Author: Dream2020#4209
Content: @Kolten thanks for your detailed explanation to me

Author: kolten
Content: Any time 🙂

Author: noahzinsmeister

Author: chrissavadge
Content:
Curious about the liquidity mining math: https://uniswap.org/blog/uni/

Aren't there about 6,500 ETH blocks / day? https://etherscan.io/chart/blocks

Then how do you get 54 UNI _per pool per block_?

Author: chrissavadge
Content: Shouldn't that be 54 UNI per block (all 4 pools combined)?

Author: kolten
Content: Sounds like you're right, unless there's something we are missing.

Author: chrissavadge
Content: OK good. I didn't figure they would be wrong but checked my calc a few times and couldn't see where I am. 🙂

Author: kolten
Content: Yeah I'm getting the same based on the description used in the post.

Author: kolten
Content:
> Hello, what % of total fees goes to UNI holders?
@Merovingian Just seeing this question. My understanding is that after a 180 day time lock delay, governance will gain control of the Uniswap fee switch—this controls 0.05% of the 0.30% protocol fee.

Author: Deleted User
Content:
> @Deleted User Speculating, but that might tip the scales on the legal calculation vis-a-vis securities laws. Compound, Coinbase, and serious players like that have good lawyers, but this is all yet to be settled as to how the SEC regards governance tokens. The team can't participate in any way that would be seen as pumping the token value, which is likely why they are explicit about not participating directly in governance:
> 
> _"The Uniswap team will continue to have no involvement in v2 protocol development, auditing, and other matters. Similarly, team members will not participate directly in governance for the foreseeable future, although they may delegate votes to protocol delegates without seeking to influence their voting decisions."_  (https://uniswap.org/blog/uni/)
@Chris Savadge interesting. Makes sense

Author: arkaydeus
Content: Hi, many people are suggesting that when governance is enabled, uni holders can vote to activate the fee switch and divert the 0.05% to themselves. My understanding was that this was a protocol improvement treasury targeted at protocol development. Can anyone confirm this?

Author: arkaydeus
Content: Seems strange that it would suddenly be redirected from protocol development to just a dividend for token holders.

Author: arkaydeus
Content: It's one thing to vote on how to improve the platform but quite another to divert resources that were supposed to be spent on developers to just token burn to enrich token holders.

Author: jab.sh
Content: @Arkaydeus for one, you need 4% of UNI to pass any votes, so unless someone is holding 4% that would never pass.

Author: arkaydeus
Content: OK but you're saying with just 4% of the vote, people could vote to divert the protocol improvement fund (the 0.05%) to token burn benefiting the token holders?

Author: arkaydeus
Content: Worth noting that the Binance.com analysis page on UNI is saying the token has the rights to the 0.05%. I've not seen that written anywhere on Uniswap.org

Author: jab.sh
Content: I'm not saying whether such a vote is possible or anything like that, simply the mechanics of voting itself.

Author: jab.sh
Content: I haven't read into the docs or the contract enough to know if such a vote would be possible

Author: arkaydeus
Content: I think this is a really crucial point. People are just saying all over the Internet that token holders get a % of fees. Yet this was never announced.

Author: jab.sh
Content: I'm pretty sure that's not true...

Author: arkaydeus
Content: Me too

Author: arkaydeus
Content: It's a protocol development fee, not a dividend to token holders fee.

Author: arkaydeus
Content: @Hayden Adams 🦄 , please can you confirm the fee switch and the resulting 0.05% fee is for protocol development, not as a token holder revenue? It was originally described as something to be used to develop the platform. Seems sensible. Wondering why people are suddenly saying otherwise.

Author: jab.sh
Content: @Arkaydeus please don't cold ping people

Author: arkaydeus
Content: Oh sorry.

Content: Once you have staked your liquidity in a UNI mining contract, you will no longer see it in the Pool tab of the Uniswap UI.  You can withdraw from the mining pool at any time and pool directly if you like, but you will stop getting UNI tokens in that case.

Author: ibnkhaldun
Content:
@metanol  Listen to yourself....The reward went out to every single person who has traded and invested on the platform for its ENTIRE existence up until 19 days ago.

It's a reward for GENUINE supporters of the platform, not parasites who come ONLY after rewards are announced.

Stop moralizing your self-interest and redirecting responsibility for your own position.

You could've been on before Sep 1st AND had multiple Wallets on the platform...

I only had one wallet on, but I'm not salty at other users for being in a better position. I accept the consequences of my actions like an adult.

I missed out on investing in Amazon when it started out because I didn't know anything about investing in high School.

I missed out on Investing in Nvidia in 2015 because I was paying off debts...
I don't get salty about these things, I get sharper and look for future opportunities.

You need to do the same...now that you know there's rewards for being an early adopter and supporter of new crypto and platforms, you'll research more and get on board.

@metanol  So because the rewards are redistribution of fees accrued, the release of the reward should have come on the same date as the announcement.

So fees should be reimbursed for everyone after Sept 1st or should everyone who entered after Sept 1st be eligible for  future rewards?

@metanol  Also how do you know  whether or not rewards were funded from any fees collected after Sept 1st. The reward program may have had a pool of fees building up that was cut off at Sept 1st

- SOCKS liquidity tokens

Author: schmeaulin
Content:
I see a bit of an issue with UNI tokens locked in pools being unable to vote.

Without liquidity, UNI can't be traded and uniswap is built on the idea of pools being healthy and saturated.

Author: schmeaulin
Content: at the same time, every UNI token locked into a pool can't be used to vote, which is a significant number of tokens. this feels like a catch 22 - pull out of the pool to cast a vote, risking your position and impermanent loss or skip a vote, risking not having a say in a potentially important matter

Author: schmeaulin
Content: would really like to see a solution for this somehow. like, being able to use LP tokens somehow for some sort of IOU vote, which can be calculated conservatively. like, 75% of your UNI worth in the pool can be used for votes or something.

Author: mr_po
Content: Hi everyone! Could anyone tell me if you have to own a certain amount of UNI to become a delegate?

Author: kolten
Content:
You need 10M UNI delegated to you to formally create a proposal. 

But since Uniswap uses Compound's gov. contracts, we could also make use of autonomous proposals. If my math is right: Using Compound's ratio would make it so that autonomous proposals only require 10,000 UNI. I believe that 10,000 number could also be adjustable. Here's a blog post detailing them: https://medium.com/compound-finance/compound-autonomous-proposals-354e7a2ad6b7

Author: schmeaulin
Content: thats awesome!

Author: mr_po
Content:
@Kolten very interesting, do you think one could use delegated 10000 UNI to create an autonomous proposal or do they have to be owned? 
So as far as I understood you don't have to own any amount of UNI on your address to be eligible for other people to delegate their voting rights to you, is that correct?

Author: kolten
Content: Yeah, I’m pretty sure that’s correct.

Author: Psilos9#5846
Content: So I think the next competitor to uniswap is going to be decentralized exchanges on L2 solutions like xdai,  seems like Uni swap could pre-empt this by the launching its own Uniswap on the L2 chains, and the community voting to incentivize LP moving to the uniswap L2 chain.  There would be a huge advantage to uniswap too if it pulled traders and LP to an L2 chain as we wouldn't even need to redistribute the .005 fee from LP's the protocol could raise fees and the cost benefit to everyone would still be positive as the overall fees paid for trade on a L2 chain would still be far less.

Author: lmat#1258
Content: I'm looking at `Timelock` in `executeTransaction`. It looks like the money is on the line `(bool success, bytes memory returnData) = target.call.value(value)(callData)`. (`callData` comes from `data` passed as a parameter).

Author: lmat#1258
Content: (here: https://github.com/compound-finance/compound-protocol/blob/master/contracts/Timelock.sol#L80)

Author: lmat#1258
Content: This looks super opaque. When a governance item is proposed, the item itself is executable code, right? And the executable code is just a smash of big numbers? How do we tell what they will actually do?

Author: lmat#1258
Content: For instance, the most recent timelock executed transaction (I think) is mentioned at the top of the page here: https://app.compound.finance/timelock and currently points to this transaction: https://etherscan.io/tx/0xe27f4a78a06ca62d9b64fcaf1c18f68182a0ec9435c4f3077468e7d428547691. The data between those two pages don't match. I assume the etherscan page is interpreting the data a bit by giving the function address (`MethodID: 0xddf0b009`)?

Author: pro dharm#3497
Content: Why price going down

Author: pro dharm#3497
Content: Of compound

Author: lmat#1258
Content: @pro dharm Which price is going down?

Author: noahzinsmeister
Content: @lmat while you make good points, timelock is as intentionally non-opaque as possible

Author: noahzinsmeister
Content: a governance vote consists of arrays of targets/values/signatures/data

Author: noahzinsmeister
Content: it's pretty trivial to turn these into human-readable function calls that can be parsed and interpreted by a human, though i will admit that this does entail some work!

Author: noahzinsmeister
Content: can't speak for the compound interface, but the https://app.uniswap.org voting interface will parse all governance proposals

Author: daochemist
Content: "1% of UNI total supply (delegated) to submit a governance proposal"

Author: daochemist
Content: "1% of UNI total supply (delegated) to submit a governance proposal"

Author: daochemist
Content: So, 10 million $UNI to create a proposal?

Author: kolten
Content: Yes, but Compound recently introduced "Autonomous Proposals" which lower the barrier to make a proposal: https://medium.com/compound-finance/compound-autonomous-proposals-354e7a2ad6b7

Author: kolten
Content: Since Uniswap's governance is based on Compound's, Autonomous Proposals can be used in Uniswap governance too.

Author: ferretknows
Content: Can. But no, Uniswap uses a different protocol. That won't change.

Author: ferretknows
Content: Just because it is based on something doesn't make it the same.

Author: kolten
Content: Out of curiosity: Why wouldn't you want Autonomous Proposals?

Author: ferretknows
Content: It doesn't matter what I want. Uniswap decided they use a different system.

Author: ferretknows
Content: Every system has its strong and weak points.

Author: kolten
Content: It's the same system, ported to Uniswap.

Author: kolten
Content: I'm only referring to governance here.

Author: ferretknows
Content: Same idea, different rules

Author: kolten
Content: I don't think the rules are different? Just what's in control?

Author: ferretknows
Content: There are advantages to not having every one be able to submit a proposal.

Author: kolten
Content: Agreed. But Autonomous Proposals don't allow anyone to make proposals.

Author: kolten
Content: You can still set a minimum.

Author: kolten
Content: And it's _just_ to make a proposal.

Author: kolten
Content: Ultimately you still have to garner the 10M UNI support.

Author: ferretknows
Content: Sure. But the idea of voting gathering is nothing new.

Author: ferretknows
Content: That can still work on Uniswap.

Author: ferretknows
Content: If I am correct we even have voting pools right now.

Author: kolten
Content: I think we might be talking past each other here. In its default form: You need 10M UNI delegated to you just to make an official proposal. Using autonomous proposals, you would need less UNI delegated to you to _make_ a proposal, but still need 10M votes delegated to the _proposal_ for it proceed into the formal governance proposal and voting process.

Author: ferretknows
Content: I understand. But it doesn't technically change the system.

Author: ferretknows
Content: Like you said, you still need the minimum amount.

Author: kolten
Content: It changes it in that the threshold to make an official proposal is lower.

Author: kolten
Content: This means you don't need 10M UNI delegated to an individual, just to a proposal.

Author: ferretknows
Content: Yes, but if that means you get a gazillion shit proposals with each their own amount of support it still won't work. These system are very much an experiment :)

Author: ferretknows
Content: Very cool, but highly experimental :(

Author: ferretknows
Content: Still, interested to see where Uniswap will go from now on.

Content:
I don't think the fee switch is on a pool by pool basis. 

Doesn't each pair contract use the factory interface (https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v2-core/blob/master/contracts/interfaces/IUniswapV2Factory.sol) to determine its fee? So if you change the fee via the factory it changes across all pools.

Author: izebeleth
Content: @🐧Hiturunk🐧- Penguin Party @Kolten it is per factory - see the uniswap v2 whitepaper

Author: izebeleth
Content: factories are independent for each erc20 pair

Author: izebeleth
Content: so it is per-pair, as far as I understand

Author: hiturunk
kolten
Content:
I thought there was only one factory? Deployed here: https://etherscan.io/address/0x5C69bEe701ef814a2B6a3EDD4B1652CB9cc5aA6f

The factory is what "powers" each pair and makes sure there is only one smart contract per unique token pair.

Author: hiturunk
Content: @Kolten I think...you're right actually.

Author: izebeleth
Content: ^^^ yes i was wrong, I thought factory was generator for each pair

Author: izebeleth
Content: apologies

Author: hiturunk
Content: Wait a minute though.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Changing the feeTo on factory contract, how does that change the feeTo on previously deployed pairs that have come out of the factory?

Author: hiturunk
Content: Let me examine the pair contract.

Author: kolten
Content: Through the factory interface

Author: kolten
Content: That each pair contract uses

Author: hiturunk
Content: So each pair token inherits the factory?

Author: kolten
Content: Believe so yeah

Author: hiturunk
Content: Hmm

Author: kolten
Content:
In the `_mintFee()` function in a pair contract: 

`address feeTo = IUniswapV2Factory(factory).feeTo();`

Author: hiturunk
Content: @Kolten Okay! That makes sense! The Press Release made it sound like it was per-pair, but I think you're exactly right. The pair is referencing the factory contract.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Hmm, that makes turning on that protocol fee switch a much less governance-intensive affair than I assumed.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Also, a much *bigger* deal. Once that fee switch hits we'll see some serious cash-flow..

Author: Promaz#5802
Content: What is the fee switch and when is his time lock mentioned

Author: kolten
Content:
Uniswap trades incur a .3% fee that accrues back to liquidity pools. Uniswap V2 has a built in “fee switch” that can be turned on to redirect 0.05% of that fee to an external address. 

After 180 days, governance will gain control of the fee switch and has the ability to decide what to do with it and any fees accrued.

Content: @daver For it as soon as the timelock comes off, very open to hearing different allocation schemes for the fees.

Author: hiturunk
Content: One idea I have heard is to allow fees to accrue in their tokens in the treasury, giving Treasury a large amount of holdings in a large variety of tokens.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Another, to buy uni from ETH/UNI to increase buying pressure, to place in treasury or distribute pro-rata to Uni holders.

Author: hiturunk
Content: There are a variety of ways we can use fees to return value to holders of Uni, and we should have a lot of discussion about it while we wait for the timelock to come off.

Author: 0xdoolb
Content:
Perhaps this is the wrong place to ask, but my message got buried in the support board, but:

If I were to delegate my uni stack to you, @🐧Hiturunk🐧- Penguin Party , what happens to my uni? Does it get locked up for a time, meaning I can't trade it? Locked up forever? If I undelegate, do you lose voting power?

I'm cautious, as I'd like to sell at some point. My free uni stack at $7 is worth more than my life savings.
However, I don't want greedy bastards to drive uniswap into the ground, because I genuinely believe in the protocol and want it to grow.

Any help would be appreciated!

Author: diethylethereum
Content: @Doolb u can remove the delegation at any time

Author: Deleted User
Content: @Doolb the delegation is until you transfer the uni, sell the uni or remove the delegation through the voting contract. Since you have to 'self-delegate' to vote, it is just a mechanism to keep track of your intent. When that changes, and you interact with the tokens as I said above then the delegation is removed. Delegating your vote, is an efficient way to to save gas, and pursue an outcome that is aligned with your beliefs.

I wish green wojaks upon you.

Author: 0age
Content: @🐧Hiturunk🐧- Penguin Party I think you're looking at the current issue with quorum all wrong

Author: 0age
Content: If you look at the current UNI delegated (https://explore.duneanalytics.com/dashboard/uniswap-governance), there's only 47.2M UNI delegated at all

Author: 0age
Content: And with a 40M quorum, that means Dharma, Gauntlet, _or_ Univalent have complete "veto power" over any action

Author: 0age
Content: That's not a healthy state, and so unless / until more UNI is being actively delegated it's just smart to break the gridlock

Author: 0age
Content: There's also a lot of good analysis backing up the 40 > 30 modification, there are very good reasons why you want a quorum high enough to prevent unilateral action

Author: hiturunk
Content: @0age Is that why you're *lowering* the quorum to give Gauntlet and Dharma unilateral action?

Author: hiturunk
Content: I simply cannot back the proposal, it is a threat to the sovereignty of Uniswap.

Author: 0age
Content: I can assure you that Gauntlet and us are not "unilateral"

Author: 0age
Content: and I also think that our combined delegation is still shy of 30M

Author: hiturunk
Content: In any case, it's 62% of all currently delegated votes.

Author: 0age
Content: Personally, I'm focused on passing the current proposal... there's broad consensus that the proposal and quorum thresholds are too high

Author: hiturunk
Content: Moreover, if you can achieve quorum on this proposal, why is the quorum a problem?

Author: 0age
Content: I mean, that was the very rationale behind Univalent in the first place

Author: 0age
Content: I'm not convinced we _can_ arrive at quorum on this

Author: 0age
Content: not with really any significant votes against

Author: hiturunk
Content: I certainly hope that you can't, the proposal is a threat to the entire governance mechanism.

Author: hiturunk
Content: And it prevents us from launching autonomous proposals which would do away with the huge requirement to propose.

Author: 0age
Content: Anyway, just wanted to drop in and share my personal perspective on the proposal

Author: hiturunk
Content: [Until we are sure that the governor contract is not switching]

Author: 0age
Content: You can be sure once the proposal has >40m votes? 😁

Author: hiturunk
Content: You are correct. We will wait and see how the proposal turns out before deploying the autonomous proposals factory.

Author: hiturunk
Content:
I don't think you'll get quorum, I certainly will do my job to prevent it. Not because I'm opposed to your airdrop which I'm more than willing to discuss, but because lowering the quorum is a huge security risk for the DAO. Some of us remember the DAO hack.

If you want your airdrop, you should discuss and propose that; not try to modify quorum to suit your goals.

Author: 0age
Content: DAO hack was a reentrancy attack

Author: 0age
Content: The clunky governance stuff is the only thing that saved holders in the end

Author: hiturunk
Content: @0age o.0 The holders were only saved by forking the entire ethereum network.

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: Who is gauntlet and who is univalent

Author: 0age
Content: No way a fork would have been coordinated if the hacked funds weren't all locked up

Author: 0age
Content: it was a drastic measure, no question

Author: 0age
Content: impossible today IMHO

Author: hiturunk
Content: @0age True. But anyway, that's not what we're here to discuss and it certainly would be impossible today.

Author: hiturunk
Content: If you want to discuss your airdrop, I'm game for that, the community *should* discuss your airdrop, but I simply cannot vote yes or encourage anyone to vote yes to lowering quorum.

Author: 0age
Content: Look — autonomous proposals are going to need lower quorum thresholds too (or a lot more UNI needs to be delegated, unlikely as more UNI pools roll out), especially when you consider that any proposal can only vote for itself

Author: 0age
Content: So if you have more than one autonomous proposal going they will sponge up a lot of votes

Author: hiturunk
Content: We have certainly been considering the staking size's affect on autonomous proposals carefully.

Author: 0age
Content: And there's a tendency for people to delegate / vote for proposals and then not change it back to something else, look at hat mechanics in MKR gov

Author: hiturunk
Content: @0age There's over 2 million uni a week entering circulation, hitting 40 million becomes less and less of a problem.

Author: 0age
Content: core point, though, is that the delegation _participation rate_ is just very low for a variety of reasons, mostly that it's pretty early in the process, but also that UNI is not all really being delegated

Author: 0age
Content: There is a _lot_ more claimed UNI than delegated

Author: hiturunk
Content: @0age I certainly agree that the amount of Uni held in a wallet with the intention of political participation is a minority of the liquidity.

Author: 0age
Content: and at the end of the day IT IS A GOVERNANCE TOKEN

Author: hiturunk
Content: Although applications like Compound are conducive to the participation [by off-chain voting of the liquid uni]

Author: hiturunk
Content: Which is an interesting dynamic to see emerging.

Author: 0age
Content: It's still pretty expensive to support off-chain voting

Author: hiturunk
Content: But it should drive participation.

Author: 0age
Content: Well, I encourage you to consider the benefits (lower proposal threshold is _critical_ for autonomous proposals) before you vote @🐧Hiturunk🐧- Penguin Party , and **everybody go out and delegate to yourself or someone you generally agree with**! 👋

Author: hiturunk
Content:
@0age o/ I have already announced to my delegators my stance and offered to accept any questions or concerns before I vote no in approx. 20~ hours.

But yes, everybody should delegate and participate to drive protocol development forward. : )

Author: kolten
Content:
To your first point: That is the agreement Dharma users _opt in_ to when choosing to use the app. It’s not a secret. I don’t think it necessarily hurts the little guy — some people _want_ that type of protection and user experience. It’s easy, safe, and usable for the average person. 

But yes, I’ve used the app. I’d call it an Ethereum smart contract wallet that has a curated UX. That curation is it’s use case. 

I think we have to be careful not to project our definitions / values on to others.

Author: hiturunk
Content: @Kolten I can't think of any other ethereum wallet that has a complete inability to make calls to smart contracts which is the central concept of Ethereum as a network.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: For the larger legitimate pools with lots of trading volume, a periodic descending price sealed bid auction is probably best (but complicated).  However, for low volume pools this can be problematic as gas fees end out being a significant cost.  Also, single unit auctions can lead to much lower efficiency for large pools with lots of fees available, and uniform price multiunit auction is problematic as you can't auto-arbitrage so it becomes much more risky to participate in the auction.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Essentially, there are no good solutions here that I can see.

Author: Deleted User
Content: Will ^^^ issues still be a problem in L2?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Yes.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Deposit and withdraw (like Augur's participation token) avoids the whole auction problem, but it means users have to participate every period.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: And many tokens would be left unwithdrawn because the gas isn't worth it to withdraw them.  Also, this solution incredibly gas inefficient.

Author: Deleted User

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Doing anything other than distributing by UNI share can be bypassed by pooling, or shuffling, or laundering, or hiding, etc.

hiturunk

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Essentially, though I'm not a huge fan of that phrase personally.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Contracts being unchanging (like Uniswap code) with voluntary migrations (like Uniswap v1 to v2).

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I dislike the idea of trying to "govern" a thing as governance has, throughout all of history, always ended up being captured.

Author: hiturunk
Content: That is an exceptionally valid point of view.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: If you are going to govern for some reason, at least pick a model where the capture is obvious and transparent (e.g., dictatorship).

Author: hiturunk
Content: Heh.

Author: hiturunk
Content: I, myself, am in agreement with you about contracts being unchanging, immutable, and permissionless; and with upgrades being a consensual process.

Author: hiturunk
Content: When the DAO hack happened I was strongly philosophically in the "Code is Law" camp, I still supported the ETH foundation fork, for what it's worth, because we could return the money and at the time it was the right thing to do for the network. But my philosophical view that the investors *should* have eaten the loss from an agreed upon risk that they undertook together was unchanged.

Author: mr_po
Content: Do I understand correctly, that there is no preparation period for the proposals? For example, if I delegate my votes, and then the delegate makes a proposal I deeply disagree on and votes on it - there's nothing I can do to revoke my voting power?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Sadly, that is what I have learned about the voting process.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Someone proposes a vote and at that moment in time everyone is locked in to whatever their delegate wants.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: In other words, don't delegate your votes to someone you don't explicitly trust.  Instead, delegate your votes to yourself and vote yourself.

Author: mr_po
Content: omg

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Someone who better understands the system may be able to speak more authoritatively on the subject, the above is my understanding which may be incorrect.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: When you delegate you are essentially saying, "here, have my votes, but I keep the UNI for future trading".

Author: mr_po
Content: what a terrible design for the delegation system, we should definitely think of reworking it. I'll create a topic on the forum in the near future

Author: mattivp
Content: and the worse part almost nobody knows this and a lot of delegation pitches on the forum say "i will declare my vote x time before i vote so you can undelegate if you disagree" which isn't possible

Author: hiturunk
Content:
We have deployed the crowd proposal factory to mainnet: 0xfb13251C994701b27CCFd4CCCcf5847aA29a3702
Anybody can now stake 1,000 uni to start an autonomous proposal.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: If UNI holders wanted to hire a contractor and pay for services, does the governance system have anything in place or readily available for payments over time?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: That is, could UNI governance *easily* (without a bunch of engineering work) initiate a Sablier Stream which then would continue to drip UNI to the contractor at an agreed rate until such time as UNI governance turned it off or the stream expires?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Or perhaps a recurring payment with a similar "recurrance until cancelled" mechanism?

Author: hiturunk
Content: @Micah Yes, a proposal should be able to target the sablier factory with appropriate calldata as far as I understand?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Are there any alternatives that you know of?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: And how hard is it to create a vote that calls arbitrary third party contract functions?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Would need to do two steps: (1) approve Sablier to spend UNI and (2) initiate the stream.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Yes, there is another streaming payments platform, Superfluid protocol

Author: sky.cactus
Content: One of my problems with governance systems is that they tend to be quite complicated to use.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Creating a Maker proposal, for example, requires a small team of engineers and quite a bit of time, and lots of auditing, etc.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: It isn't just "do X then Y".

Author: hiturunk
Content: @Micah Agreed, it's very technical at this point, a proposal has to be fed very specific arguments [target address, calldata]

Author: sky.cactus
Content: And I'm guessing it is more complicated than just crafting a single method call?  Do I have to create a whole contract that matches some interface?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Is this process documented somewhere that you know of?

Author: hiturunk
Content: Not very well, no, I had to examine compound proposals to understand how they are called.

Author: hiturunk
Content: @Micah https://etherscan.io/tx/0x21782a40119c31cc05f9d6b34c309f3b9c14ec934f1b2733d4f309a6181b53f9

Author: hiturunk
Content: Here is a compound proposal creation that demonstrates the process

Author: hiturunk
Content: You should be able to initiate a sablier stream from one singular proposal

Author: hiturunk
Content: And with no middleware contract

Author: sky.cactus
Content: That looks like it was called from a contract, could that be called from any Ethereum account and it would have worked out just the same?

Author: hiturunk
Content: Yes.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Er, I guess it **must** be called from an account that has 1M delegated UNI?

Author: hiturunk
Content: ^ Exactly, but yes. Using our autonomous proposals factory we deployed to mainnet today, anyone can begin circulating autonomous proposal with 1,000 uni

Author: hiturunk
Content: We thought that was fair amount

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Is there a short gist on the autonomous proposals thing somewhere?  A TL;DR.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Uh, yes, basically, you stake an amount of uni to deploy an autonomous proposal from our factory, then people can delegate to newly created contract until it has enough to formally submit the proposal it holds, then it self-destructs and returns it's held uni to the proposal creator after voting yes.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Essentially. Many such AP's have been circulated on compound if you want to check that out, I can dig one up and link it for you if you'd like

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I would be more interested in a user friendly blog post at the moment, if I decide to actually submit a proposal I would likely do a more thorough audit of the code.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Trying to gauge how much work/effort I should put into this line of thinking at the moment though, so just information gathering.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Certainly! I will write up a blog post about exactly how it all works and post it on my medium!

Author: hiturunk
Content: Creating a front-end should be relatively easy, Robert Leshner from compound frequents uniswap chat, so he should be able to help with a front-end to simplify autonomous proposal viewing/creating just like their leaderboard on compound.finance.

Author: hiturunk
Content: We plan to build one ourselves for Uniswap, maybe then Uniswap team could PR it in?

Author: hiturunk
Content: Save Uniswap the work. 😄

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I'm not part of the Uniswap team.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Just someone who has been hanging out here since before it was cool.  😉

Author: sky.cactus
Content: For the curious, I recently started up an Ethereum support services business and my first set of hires are nearly finished training (several of the yellow names here in Uniswap Discord are my team, as we use this server for practice/training).  The goal is to provide 24/7 support services for Ethereum applications in their own Discord servers.  Originally, the plan was to approach the Uniswap team and offer services directly to them, but with the introduction of UNI it seems like it *may* be a better fit to propose that governance pays for it with the UNI coffers instead.

Author: hiturunk
Content: We at Penguin Party would be happy to help with that.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Getting it proposed, getting it passed..

Author: hiturunk
Content: You guys have been essential in supporting the customers of Uniswap

Author: hiturunk
Content: You add a lot of value to our community.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: So I'm trying to explore how hard that would be.  One of the challenges is that we were going to do "utility pricing", meaning you pay for what you use.  However, that is a lot more complicated when you need a governance proposal to pay every bill.  I'm trying to figure out if there is some mechanism by which we could come up with a flat-rate that is "probably enough to not have to worry about overages".  The other issue is that UNI is volatile, so having a contract for UNI rather than USDC or DAI (or even ETH) introduces a lot of risk to the company.  I can cover that by charging more, or I have to do something more complicated like setup a contract that somehow trustlessly swaps governance UNI for DAI and then puts *that* into the Sablier stream.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: It is all very complicated, which is worrisome, and why I'm trying to better understanding the process at least.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Can I invite you to our discord so we can talk about supporting you on that mission?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Sure.

Author: Deleted User
Content: This has all the appearances of a **corporate raid** on the Public Uni treasury. If that is not the case, it is a ham handed swap out of the existing Governance Contract. The Autonomous Proposal Contract that Penguin Party just Launched from Compound github was deployed to mainnet and points to** the existing Uniswap governance contract**. Autonomous Proposals were intended to allow discussion on new ideas, NOT a bum-rush to outright replace the Uniswap Governance contract which is what  Dharma is doing here. Dharma's actions make me sad, and I question their motive in handling this matter.

Author: 0age
Content: Listen — there are a few talking points being thrown around here that are pretty ridiculous in my personal opinion

Author: Deleted User
Content: If Dharma's proposal were to pass, it will break the existing Governance model, the funtioning process was designed to allow Autonomous Proposals, changing the Governance Contract Address will break what has already been deployed.  Dharma has stated this is their intent and that they are unhappy with the Status Quo. Well fortunately for our community, Governance is slow, and hard, and people take consideration of the long term implications of rash actions.  None of what Dharma has proposed is approriate for a growing community. Lowering the quorum threshold and voting limits are both subject areas that will have to be amended in the near future to prevent Governance Capture.

Content: For a proposal to pass, two important requirements must be met. first, quorum needs to be reached (this currently means 40m YES votes), and a simple majority must be met (more yes than no votes).

Author: schmeaulin
Content:
My take from this all is that UNI created a governance token which is incompatible with its own platform. 

I as a uni liquidity provider on Uniswap am being punished for performing one of the core mechanics on which the platform is built by making me unable to participate in voting as long as I provide liquidity. 

On top of that, i can not unstake now and (self) delegate to vote against or for something after the proposal has already been made, which is a massive boost for bad actors who can literally surprise us with proposals out of the blue, with no way of preparing for an upcoming vote event like that.

Author: schmeaulin
Content: So currently, governance and actual usage are mutually exclusive.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Liquidity mining doesn't really do that IMO.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The set of people who use CEXs and the set of people who use DEXs has some overlap, but I don't think liquidity mining is a significant differentiator.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: At least, not compared to all of the other differentiators.

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: do u guys think we'll get to use L2 as beta? or we'd have to wait until full release

Author: agusx1211
Content: If we want to compete with CEXs we need L2, and infrastructure to use that L2 (wallets, ramps, users, etc)

Author: mmoossttaaffaa#6983
Content:
> do u guys think we'll get to use L2 as beta? or we'd have to wait until full release
@ifunoinsideuyield  I remember a tweet from Hayden few months ago saying that V3 won't be on L2 and V3 will mostly be about increasing liquidity efficiency and lowering slippage... but L2 development is moving fast

Author: agusx1211
Content: even loopring has a hard time, and they have everything working, but they don't have the infrastructure

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I'm not convinced that trading speed is a real problem people care significantly about.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Trading *costs* are a real problem, though Uniswap swaps are incredibly cheap already, so I'm not sure L2 would really help much on that front.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: *Maybe* you get a 50% reduction in trading costs (optimistic, but maybe possible with an optimized L2).

Author: Alpha#5007
Content: Trading speed is a different kind of costs, time, will eventually became opportunity costs.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Studies in the past have shown that below some threshold, increasing trading speed doesn't actually improve price efficiency.

Author: Alpha#5007
Content: The opportunity cost is very little so to speek.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I think it also depends on what you are trying to build.  If you are trying to build a place where people can swap token A for token B, then your requirements may be quite different from if you are trying to build a place where people can gamble and compete.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: There is probably more money in building a gambling site like NYSE or CME.  😉

Author: Alpha#5007
Content: Right.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: But it is significantly easier to build a site that lets people convert between tokens.

Author: mmoossttaaffaa#6983

Author: 0age
Content: I can share some high-level info that demonstrates what happened

Author: tizaforthepeople
Content: that'd be great

Author: 0age
Content: There were 320 votes in total out of 1583 total addresses able to vote

Author: 0age
Content: now, a lot of those addresses didn't have a lot of UNI in them anyway, and there are also quite a few votes with small UNI amounts on both sides, but at the end of the day there were 272 FOR votes and 48 AGAINST

Author: 0age
Content: (remember, the 1583 able to vote represents all the accounts that have been delegated to with UNI _at the time the proposal is introduced_ — happily, the "voter base" has nearly doubled since then)

Author: 0age
Content: But what it comes down to is this — **as long as the quorum threshold stays above 51% of the total delegated UNI, against votes and abstaining votes are equivalent**

Author: 0age
Content: Of course, you can still use against votes to send a signal

Author: hiturunk
Content: @Tiza for the people The blocktime on the proposal was hit. The "Voting ends approximately" was just a guess of when that block would be.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Regardless of how anyone voted, they didn't garner support within the established block time of the code.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Code is law.

Author: 0age
Content: But there's no functional difference, you'd use one when you want to be explicit and build a voting record and the other when you a) didn't know or care about it, b) want to conceal your intentions or at least try to stay impartial, or c) have some issue, technical or otherwise, that prevents you from being able to cast a vote

Author: chrisblec
Content: I'd like to speak up in favor of @codebam's general idea for an autonomous delagate contract that auto-votes "no" every time. I can't speak to the tech aspects but in theory, I think the idea is fantastic. It will ensure that anyone seeking "yes" votes has to do the work of bringing their message to the community and encouraging people to vote in their favor, rather than trying to slip a proposal through in darkness like they so often do.

Author: chrisblec
Content: I do believe that voters should vote "no" by default, unless they are truly swayed by an argument. We obv should not be voting "yes" by default as so often happens with Maker and Compound.

Author: chrisblec
Content: Creating an autonomous "no" whale would be an amazing test for the ability of tokenized governance to serve the needs of the users

Author: kolten
Content:
> but a 48 hour delay would ease that concern

Backed this up on the forum, but will do so here too. 

One of my concerns is information lag — this helps mitigate that. It’s not the case that delegation = blind trust, but the current proposal -> vote timing assumes that’s the case. 

48 hours is plenty of time to see a proposal, do analysis, and see where your delegate’s head is at. If you disagree, you can re-delegate for that proposal.

Author: kolten
Content:
> @Kolten  Maker governance works somewhat differently but yeah, same basic principle
@danrobinson  Oh yeah, the system is definitely different. I just remember the attack vector being ~ basically ~ the same.

Author: 0age
Content: It’d be pretty straightforward to implement as well — assume that delegation to zero address at snapshot is a self-delegation when determining candidacy for voting weight on each proposal

Author: dan_robinson
Content:
> @danrobinson  Oh yeah, the system is definitely different. I just remember the attack vector being ~ basically ~ the same.
@Kolten  Indeed it was a way scarier attack. If you could reach quorum by yourself, you could just propose and pass any proposal atomically before anyone else was able to even vote against (I think even using flash borrowed MKR!). And Maker governance proposals had the ability to steal all the collateral in Maker

Author: dan_robinson
Content:
> It’d be pretty straightforward to implement as well — assume that delegation to zero address at snapshot is a self-delegation when determining candidacy for voting weight on each proposal
@0age  That’s an interesting idea

Content: Doesn’t solve the issue of “what if my delegate tricked me”

Author: dan_robinson
Content: Yeah

Author: jimz#2082
Content: because transferring from an address to another doesn't mean transfer of actual ownership necessarily. if i'm moving my tokens from one wallet to another, do we err on the side of reverting to self-delegation or do we keep where they are

Author: 0age
Content: When you move your tokens, you give the recipient the right to choose how to delegate them

Author: dan_robinson
Content:
> when tokens are transferred are they automatically returned to self-delegation?
@jimz  same as currently happens. They would become delegated to whoever the person who receives them is delegated to

Author: 0age
Content: If they have a delegate set, they accrue to that delegate

Author: 0age
Content: If they don’t, they accrue to themselves

Author: 0age
Content: Easy

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
https://discordapp.com/channels/597638925346930701/755969053280960533/767916018772738088
 @danrobinson I'm just catching up, but a "just-vote-no" delegate would address this for all but a full 51% attack.  It would make it so that everyone delegates to a no voter by default, unless they explicitly delegate away from that.  It means that for a proposal to pass, you must have 51% explicit approval+abstain essentially.

Author: dan_robinson

Content: Oh, I would recommend *everyone* delegate to an autonomous contract that votes no for everything except the proposal they want.

Author: dan_robinson
Content: The token contract snapshots how much every address has delegated to it, but doesn’t snapshot how much the address itself has

Author: sky.cactus
Content: No one should ever delegate to something non-autonomous.  It is way too risky that you'll inadvertantly participate in an attack.

Author: dan_robinson
Content: I think there can be good reasons to delegate

Author: sky.cactus
Content: (I personally think the current governance system is entirely ridiculous, and I'm looking for the simplest/smallest change that gets rid of the whole concept of locking in votes prior to the vote)

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Delegating is a 100% trusted operation.  If you want to do that, great, but there should be a way to participate in governance that is simple and doesn't require any trust.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The current system requires you delegate to yourself, which means you then need to pay attention to governance, which most people won't do closely.

Author: daochemist
Content:
> Rewarding ETH/UNI is not rewarding UNI holders, is rewarding UNI holders that are market making (and thus also exposing their ETH)
@Agusx1211 that is true, but it is farmers who adding selling pressure on top of the inflation. If we give them a reason to hodl, we also give a reason for short sellers to think twice, and hence indirectly, that benefits all $UNI hodlers. There has to be a sink in the token model, otherwise there's too much of a misalignment for farmers not to dump the $UNI we incentivize them to farm but not to hodl.

Author: daochemist
Content: "show me the incentive, I'll show you the outcome." There is an incentive to farm, but no incentive to hodl. A rational actor will dump. And there's no reason for them not to do for at least another 6 months.

Author: daochemist
Content: The goal of the $UNI incentives is to spread the $UNI ownership to as many users as possible and to further the decentralization of the governance. This is a worthy goal, but it doesn't work if the farmers dump. A way to fix this, while keeping this goal for further decentralization, is to add an incentive to the UNI/ETH pool.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Uni holders need to get a value exchange.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Uni holders need to get something out of voting yes.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Our thought at Penguin Party was: By incorporating features like ability to vote uni in their wallet.

Author: hiturunk
Content: [and comp]

Author: hiturunk
Content: Then they could get a grant from the uniswap treasury.

Author: hiturunk
Content: And every proxy contract could kind of individually get a grant.

Author: hiturunk
Content: [voted on by uniswap holders]

Author: hiturunk
Content: Instead of an all-at-once package deal.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Maybe the proxy contracts could or SHOULD get more than they're asking for [over a longer period] for building features that expand uniswap's common use and interoperability?

Author: hiturunk
Content: So instead of just saying: "This company missed an airdrop" we can turn this in to a situation where we put companies that are building on uniswap on a pedastal and say: "What you're developing is important to Uniswap, here's x amount of money to keep developing your use of uniswap."

Author: hiturunk
Content: And this precedent being set, of using uniswap treasury to fund grants to build software features that benefit all users and the ecosystem, would be healthy for everyone.

Author: hiturunk
Content: That's how we want to see the airdrop discussion reframed.

Author: hiturunk
Content: These proxy contract users deserve uni too, but there are already investors in Uni. We could retroactively get these companies a way to get uni [to give to their users and get a say in uniswap] by offering uni holders software development deliverables in exchange.

Author: hiturunk
Content: That would solve everyone's problems and keep the "airdrops" from just resulting in huge dumps and a price crash of Uni.

Author: hiturunk
Content: The main thing we should be spending the uniswap treasury on is developing software and extending use of v2 while the devs develop layer 2.

Author: hiturunk
Content: : ) That way, too, as we solve each company's "airdrop" if it really did cause sell pressure, at least it wouldn't be all at once.

Author: hiturunk
Content: I'm talking about stuff like Furucombo.

Author: hiturunk
Content: The users on their list had normal web 3 wallets, and would have qualified as users in the first airdrop, but were excluded because their only use  was through furucombo's proxy contracts. But, the beauty of thinking of these more as development grants is: Then it's not really about how many users.

Author: hiturunk
Content: It's about, are these apps contributing to the uniswap contracts and defi ecosystem?

Author: hiturunk
Content: Does their integration provide value addition to uni holders? In a lot of cases, I think: yes.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Being able to flash loan with furucombo then arbitrage on uniswap and other defi exchanges and take a profit is hugely value additive and drives use of our platform.

Author: hiturunk
Content: It opens these complex defi services up to the average user to take advantage of.

Author: hiturunk
Content: That's my problem too with the retroactive airdrop proposal: We're talking about just lumping every single app in to one big package and doing an airdrop.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Instead of giving grants to these companies to keep building great software that makes uniswap better.

Author: hiturunk
Content: [and evaluating on a case-by-case basis what value they may add]

Author: Deleted User
Content:
@brendan_dharma  @DonYakka🥷 

# MVP for Applications and UNI Governance Partnership

An application MUST provide an easy access to:

# A Link to the [Uniswap Governance](https://app.uniswap.org/#/vote) page through the primary portal, or view that the end user interacts with.

Verbiage SHOULD be copied from the UNI Governance page as such in the interface for the applcation:

[Uniswap Governance](https://app.uniswap.org/#/vote)

UNI tokens represent voting shares in Uniswap Governance. You can vote on each proposal yourself or delegate your votes to a third party.
[Read more about Uniswap Governance](https://uniswap.org/blog/uni/)

# Exceptions

* If the application does not support browser transactions and web3, the functionality for web3 support MUST be implemented so that UNI in the user's wallet can be;

1. Self Delegated, or
2. Delegated to an Ethereum Address or ENS name.

* The application MUST provide an ability to visibly confirm which address, the user has delegated to. If the user is self delgated, this should be emphasized if the the users wallet address is not easily viewed when checking the UNI balance.

* The application MUST provide an ability to view current UNI Governance proposals, and whether they have been passed or not.

* The application MUST provide an ability to vote current UNI Governance proposals, and notify the user when the voting is ended.

* For transactions that end in the user holding UNI, an alert to Self Delegate OR Delegate to an Ethereum Address OR ENS Name MUST be raised and require a user to actively DECLINE delegation.

* Any view of the user wallet MUST show that UNI tokens are either delegated, or provide a link to begin the delegation workflow.

Author: brendan_dharma#3173
Content:
We have been working on this proposal since the day that UNI was released. We worked round the clock with several stakeholders to pull together a viable proposal. 

Univalent amassed 10m votes with the express purpose of lowering the voting thresholds. While we wouldn't have pursued that on our own, Univalent made clear that they would not vote for any other proposals. So that was 10m votes that were not available for our proposal. And there were only 47m UNI delegated at all, which made our proposal impossible to pass without Univalent.

Then we got frustrated with Univalent because even though they had the votes to make the proposal, as well as the vocal support of us and other delegations, they were dragging their feet in submitting the formal proposal. So we submitted exactly the proposal that they wanted, in the hope that after proposal, whether passed or not, Univalent would dissolve and their 10m votes would become available to use for other proposals.

Author: brendan_dharma#3173
Content: For further context, it's not "3 delegates". Dharma has 66 delegates, and Univalent has >400. This *was* a community-driven proposal

Author: brendan_dharma#3173
Content:
> @brendan_dharma because the whole idea of decentralizing governance is to take it out of the hands of the company and put it into the hands of the users???
@Chris Blec Hmm, I think there is nuance to this. 

First off, "decentralizing", IMO, is the movement towards less concentration of power. Moving from 1 decision maker to 2-of-3 vote would be "decentralizing". IMO, "decentralizing" does not intrinsically mean "put power in the hands of users". 

Secondly, the initial UNI distribution did a lot to decentralize Uniswap's governance, and UNI inflation will continue to increase decentralization.

Finally, whether you like it or not, investors and team members hold tokens right now. It's hard for me to understand the logic by which delegating their votes to Dharma is not an increase in decentralization

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: okay another crucial point

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: to support the value of uni, we need a mechanism to prevent farm project owners from abusing the pool

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: ideally some mechanism to discourage or disrupt creating farm projects that add value to their ownproject while dumping uni on the open market

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: many of us at PP were brainstorming a potential reward claim delay bonus

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: for example, if you delay your reward claim by 1 month, your reward increases by 10%, if you delay the reward by 2 months, your reward increases by 20%

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: we could cap it at a certain point or adjust the numbers

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: but essentially, letting farming projects build on top of our pool incentive will simply continue to erode the price of UNI for the benefit of UNI-shorters and farm project longers

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: I know @DaoChemist  you were the most concerned about the constant market sell pressure so this is somthing you should be pushing for with me in the PP, instead of syupporting the "AS IS" eth/uni pool concept

Author: sky.cactus
Content: We (presumably) want to minimize the opportunity cost for voting on governance proposals to maximize the percentage of UNI that actually participates in governance.  To do that, we need to make it so there is little to be gained by locking up your UNI, not further reward people for it.

Content: Keep in mind, the vast majority of software engineers are *really bad* at estimating timelines.  😉

Author: sky.cactus
Content: So I'm sure there will be people who will tell you that it is "easy, will only take me a week or two".  However, they likely aren't accounting for time spent debugging, auditing, testing, integration testing, getting all of the infrastructure up for testing and auditing, operational work around the deployment, etc.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: It turns out, for security critical software writing the code is the easy part.  😄

Author: daochemist
Content:
> wrap uni/eth lp to vuni for voting
@qklpj.eth that makes sense. I think it's better to decouple incentivizing from voting into two proposals. We get the first one out, we build momentum, we pass the first proposal, and subsequently we create a second proposal, get a developer to implement the change, audit the code, and get that second out. Binding the two is not the most efficient to go about it, IMO.

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: the UNI/xxx pool looks like its incentivising uni holding at first glance but it could very easily devolve into uni whales who are using external farming projects to increase their uni rewards, which increase the yields of their external project, which allows them to dump uni at a higher rate than previously

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: this increases the price of their external project, lowers the price of uni, and all they have to do to get a quick 2x or 5x or 10x on their entire portfolio is to long their project and short uni

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: without a mechanism that encourages people to hold their rewards and not claim them immediately and sell them on the open market, uni's price will continue to dump from inflation, guaranteed.

Content: The point of liquidity mining isn't to boost UNI price, in fact it *hurts* UNI price because it increases circulating supply.  The point of liquidity mining is to increase Uniswap liquidity in targeted pools.  You should assume that *all* liquidity miners are immediately selling when evaluating whether liquidity mining is a good idea or not.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: This is essentially how governance capture *always* works.  You introduce rules that narrow the scope of people who can participate in an activity, and you narrow them such that you are inside the scope and some set of people are outside the scope.

Author: Bob_The_Buidler | YFIStats.com#4160
Content: But this doesn't narrow the scope

Author: Bob_The_Buidler | YFIStats.com#4160
Content: In any way

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Over time, you narrow the scope more and more until eventually you are the only remaining actor who is able to participate.

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Sure it does.  You go from saying "anyone who adds liquidity gets UNI".  You are proposing we change it to "anyone who adds liquidity with an EOA gets UNI".  This is narrowing the scope of people who are allowed to mine liquidity such that you are included and others are not.

Author: Bob_The_Buidler | YFIStats.com#4160

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The core devs are *actively* seeking to prevent this exact type of behavior by the way.  It goes against a core principle of Ethereum where the *idea* is that everyone has contract wallets.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Unfortunately, a lot of projects disallow the use of contract wallets (like proposed here), which means everyone in the ecosystem operates with lower levels of security than they should.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Interestingly, in traditional governments (e.g., US, EU, etc.), governance capture takes on this exact form.  In a modern democracy lobbyists lobby for and introduce restrictions that make doing a particular job just a little bit harder, but in such a way as it is easier for the people paying the lobbyists to do that task than everyone else.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The proposed regulations always fix some alleged problem, and "protect the people", but they also always increase the barrier to entry into the market.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Eventually, you end up with something like the ISP situation in the US, where regulations are so strict and onerous that it is effectively impossible for any new players to enter the game.  You cannot just setup an ISP and start serving your neighbors, you can only participate if you are a multi-billion dollar company.

Author: agusx1211
Content:
I have nothing against Navad, Brendan, Chris, Hiturunk or the Uniswap team, and I think governance of Uniswap is going to be just fine

But at the end of the day this project belongs to the Uniswap team, and judging by the few interactions I had with them... whatever I am trying to do is not being welcomed, and I couldn't be more uncomfortable with that

I wouldn't want someone insisting on taking part of my project if I don't like what they are doing either, so I think is best if that I take a step to the side.

I will keep working on my things and projects, some of them are Uniswap integrations... luckily for me I can interact with Uniswap without having to participate on this gov process 

Good luck everyone!

The solution to that problem. I honestly think there was:
<https://gov.uniswap.org/t/retroactive-airdrop-excludes-proxy-contract-users-e-g-dharma-matcha-etc/1222/7>

At this point the problem was stated, but without a solution. But there was definitely discussion around the solution as well starting around here:
<https://gov.uniswap.org/t/retroactive-airdrop-excludes-proxy-contract-users-e-g-dharma-matcha-etc/1222/35>

Side notes, I don't care which way the proposal goes, and I do wish chris acted as a more neutral moderator, but that's my personal opinion.

Author: hodldwon
Content:
I think the insurance spaces are a bit crowded already. I do like the ideas about uni allowing lending... Maybe... But realize lending is a two edged sword.

If you can borrow, you can short.

Author: hodldwon
Content: Also, lending covers the IL problem. You just LP both sides, and borrow the exact amount of the side you don't want exposure to.

Author: hodldwon
Content: Uniswap could actually integrate it much more seamlessly though by having your short position follow you LP position.

Author: hodldwon
Content: But with that said, in traditional markets Options seem to always be the cheapest method of hedging against IL.

Author: DonYakka🥷#2017
Content: Yes but allowing all erc20 tokens

Author: hodldwon
Content: Can't allow all ERC20 tokens. Someone is always taking the other side of a trade/borrow. So caps and limits have to be put in. Otherwise a malicious token can steal assets.

Author: hodldwon
Content: Dark Forest and all that...

Content: Well the borrowing limit is determined by what the user puts as collateral and how much supply there is for that particular token

Author: mushini
Content:
I predicted your response correctly. I saw codebam's last responses, and they seemed a lot more like misunderstanding and disagreement than just plain FUD. "there's no way you did this just for the gas," "except that they tried to lower quorum so they could change whatever they wanted" These comments aren't just straight FUD, they're a bit on the accusatory side and I think he went too far, probably believing he was safe to do so. However, it's extremely minor, and he's *also* illustrating what he believes to be threat vectors. A permanent ban from the Discord seems heavy-handed (was he also banned from the governance forum?). He seemed to be a dev and someday he might be a good solidity/ethereum developer. There's been an increasing defense afforded to Dharma. You "obviously" banned him for being useless and annoying, nothing more. When Noah said he was "actively" spreading disinformation, he was likely implying he was *intentionally* and *actively* doing so. My main point is just that a permaban seems too heavy-handed, it's not good for the whole. I don't know if you had other reasons for the ban.

Also, I've looked a few times and I don't see a rule in #📙│rules  that disallows "cold mentioning" people. I've seen Micah ask people *several* times not to cold mention people, but I'm not sure if he means just @ admins or @ everyone.

Author: jimz#2082
Content: thanks for your kind words. i have no idea and no bone to pick in whatever happened - i was probably sleeping and it's none of my business anyway. but this sort of conflict is definitely something we need to figure out how to address on a level that at least, even if one side will find themselves losing, be okay with losing because the trust the system (the essence of democracy, or decentralized , governance is that it has to be valid enough that it makes losing sometimes at least acceptable), not in every case, but most cases. is there any way we can set up something like a working group of interested to hash out governance in some more ordered ways? i'm a a lawyer (criminal defense and immigration/administrative), and i know some others in the community are too, but being a financial institution we need participation from that end too, and developers as well, and non-experts because it's very easy to go full wonky and lose track of who the customers and community members are.

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: @DaoChemist not without farm abuse mitigation

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: Without it, all your goals end up extending the abuse, especially allowing farmers to vote

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content:
Right now, a decent percentage of the LP's are not LP'ing directly with Uniswap, but instead with external farming projects. All they're doing is farming UNI, dumping immediately to cause nonstop-built in sell pressure, and then pumping up the price of their external farm project token to dump and rugpull on the newbs. 

By enabling a new UNI pool and allowing LP's to vote where large uni whales are already involved with the external farm projects to potentially farm a larger percentage of the UNI rewards, it could potentially make the price dumping even more severe and it would allow them to vote in favor of more dumping to favor short term gains over the long term goals of UNI. They could 5x short uni and long their token and multiply their bags in short order.

I propose a 2 month time lock on the uni rewards and an additional incentive for each month the reward claim is delayed (for example, each month after they get an additional 10% bonus on their entire rewards)

This will stop the farms in their tracks as it'll  be hard to convince anyone that a farm wont rug pull after 2 months or they'll create vesting tokens that might be worthless if the team rugpulls as well.

If anyone proposes a new liquidity pool without Farm Abuse Mitigation (FAM), it's our duty to vote NO.

Content: Great sounding idea

Author: ifunoinsideuyield#5766
Content: thank you @thugxnasty . A lot of people are finally waking up to this as the real problem and its up to us to be vigilant about making it known and not to align ourselves with those who intend to extend the abuse by releasing an "AS IS" liquidity pool reward without FAM that will extend the abuse or potentially make it even more severe

Author: daochemist
Content: $UNI is a utility token, and the team wants to keep it that way. Both BTC and ETH have been deemed to be decentralized enough not to be securities anymore. So I think the Uniswap is hoping that its decentralized governance will afford it the same status. For example, if the team had created an incentive to the UNI/ETH pool, that could be considered making $UNI an investment. Not so if that same feature is introduced as a result of the community of $UNI holders deciding so.

Author: dkrillacielo.finance
Content: Then the community can and should do things to add value to the UNI token

Author: daochemist
Content: I agree. I think better than burning tokens based on the assumption that future proposals will not benefit or add value to the UNI token, we should focus on passing proposals that do add value to UNI. I see at least two options to do so, (1) removing selling pressure by removing the existing $UNI incentives, or (2) adding buying pressure by adding $UNI incentive to the UNI/ETH pool.

Content: I like (2) because greed works.

Content: The real question behind everything: Is Uni an equity? Are we using Uni as an entitlement to the future profits of the platform? I think the answers are yes. Author: brendan_dharma#3173
Content:
I view the benefits being:
1. increase UNI hodling incentive by providing UNI holders with revenue opportunity (though I view turning on protocol fees to be the better option)
2. (speculative) decrease amount of UNI on CEXs thus (speculative) decreasing likelihood of bad governance behavior by CEXs  

I view the costs as:
1. UNI locked in the pool wouldn't be able to vote, so negative impact on governance participation
2. needless juicing of UNI/ETH pool LPing (ie no reason in my mind that this market needs to be subsidized, other than to give UNI holders revenue option)

Author: brendan_dharma#3173
Content: So in short, I think it's a mixed-bag

Author: DonYakka🥷#2017
Content: I like your thinking and mindset bro

Author: daochemist
Content:
> So in short, I think it's a mixed-bag
@brendan_dharma thanks for providing this feedback. I agree with the costs. For the first one, there's already talks of enabling LP to votes, so hopefully it can be addressed in a subsequent proposal. For the second, I agree but I would say it's an needed incentive to prevent farmers from selling and short sellers from continuously dumping on holders. I think Augusx1211 also said something similar, that the incentive felt artificial. I get that, but IMO that's the best fix we got that doesn't require new code, audit, etc, etc. Again, a more long term sink would be better indeed.

Author: brendan_dharma#3173
Content: Why is it imperative to prevent "farmers from selling and short sellers from continuously dumping on holders"?

Author: daochemist
Content:
> Why is it imperative to prevent "farmers from selling and short sellers from continuously dumping on holders"?
@brendan_dharma cuz most of the community is made out of hodlers, and I think the reason most people hodl $UNI is the belief that the token (should) capture some of the value of the platform. So it's painful to see the platform grow but the token depreciate continuously.

Content: On a side note, I think we'd get some extremely valuable data if there was no immediate continuation of LP incentives after the current program runs out

Content: to see how much liquidity stays

Author: Tharsonius#5862
Content: I think many people would favour activating the fee switch if it was possible right away, the pool incentive should be considered as more of a remedy to that "flaw"

Author: daochemist
Content:
> Incentivizing the UNI/ETH pool will not accomplish the goal of creating a "relation between Uniswap and $UNI"
@brendan_dharma True, I agree, and that's why it feels artificial to many. But it will curb the short selling and the farmers dumping (which is based an articificial incentive of $UNI). Now I am not saying two wrongs make a right, but I understand the pool incentives are meant to grow the network, the number of $UNI holders so that further decentralize the Uniswap governance. So I get why the Uniswap team did that, but unfortunately, without an incentive to hodl, farmers dump (and short sellers have a field day). So this incentive further this goal of growing the network and curbs the "bad" incentives, that's why I see it as a fix, rather then a solution.

Author: mr_po
Content: and on another side note, just the discontinuation of LP incentives on the 4 main pairs relieves quite a bit of selling pressure from the UNI token too

Author: mr_po
Content: so maybe if you care about UNI buyers not being in the red, there should be no LP program at all

Author: mr_po
Content: at least until the fee switch is activated

Author: daochemist
Content:
> and on another side note, just the discontinuation of LP incentives on the 4 main pairs relieves quite a bit of selling pressure from the UNI token too
@Po That makes sense. But I don't know a successful token without a value capture. So, this makes sense in theory, but in practice, good tokens give hodlers a reason to hodl. I don't know that governance alone is a strong narrative. In 6 months, with the switch happens, all good. Until then, I do think $UNI needs a value capture, a narrative, a reason to hodl. IMO.

Author: mr_po
Content: the reason to hold UNI is the expectation that in 6 months the fee switch is activated, imo it's quite reasonable

Author: mr_po
Content: it can't have value capture before that

Author: mr_po
Content: more than that, every UNI spent on the Liquidity program, will benefit UNI holders much more after the switch is activated

Author: mr_po
Content: as bigger liquidity means bigger volume means bigger rewards that come from 0.05% of that volume

Author: mr_po
Content: so I think the better way to approach the coming 6 months is to chill and build the infrastructure. the treasury funds don't have an expiration date

Author: daochemist
Content:
> the reason to hold UNI is the expectation that in 6 months the fee switch is activated, imo it's quite reasonable
@Po I disagree. 6 months in crypto is a long time. From now until then, we have plenty of data telling us what will happen to the $UNI token. I know some people thought the sharp depreciation was market related, but I think by now there is a consensus that it is due to the current token model. I understand your point, but the market is also making a point. If the market was making that point every now and then, that'd be one thing, but it has made that point consistently every week. So, IMO, a fix is needed to prevent $UNI from consistently and systematically leaking value.

Author: DonYakka🥷#2017
daochemist
Content: I think sometimes price is misunderstood as a reflection of speculation. Price is the most decentralized feedback mechanism. It is the aggregate of all the opinions on a given asset or commodity. The feedback it gives should be included in our conversation, especially if that feedback  is consistant over time.

Content:

@Po So, before I answer that, do you see any problem with my assessment of the situation so far?

Author: daochemist
Content: Do you agree that there might be an issue with token model in its current form?
