Content: what do you mean when saying token model? I think it's awesome

Author: daochemist
Content:
> yes, I think there's not enough data to make that conclusion
@Po Cool, that's fair. The problem I have is that $UNI shouldn't have been released in its current form. And we shouldn't have provided incentives that leak value off $UNI. As a community, all actors self-interests should be aligned. There shouldn't be a misalignement of interests, where some actors interests are put to the side for a given reason. In other words, as a holder, I don't want to subsidize farmers.

Author: mr_po
Content: then you shouldn't vote for continuation of liquidity mining program

Author: daochemist
Content:
> then you shouldn't vote for continuation of liquidity mining program
@Po You're blending problem with solution. I'm trying to get to a consensus on what the problem is, you keep jumping forward towards an eventual solution.

Author: daochemist
Content: Are the interests of holders and farmers aligned currently?

Author: mr_po
Content: well, tbh I don't view the present reality as a problem. The initial distribution and the initial liquidity mining program is the reality, it's just there

Author: daochemist
Content: if the token model works as is, then the major actors, i.e hodlers, farmers, developers and early investors, there should be some alignment, but there should not misalignment where one set of actors benefit at the cost of another set of actors

Author: daochemist
Content: would you not agree with that?

Author: mr_po
Content: with the maxima that one set of actors shouldn't benefit at the cost of others, absolutely. That's in my program 🙂

Author: daochemist
Content:
> with the fact that one set of actors shouldn't benefit at the cost of others, absolutely. That's in my program 🙂
@Po great! So if you were to see such a misalignment, you would agree that this is a flaw in the token model, right?

Author: mr_po
Content: you see, @DaoChemist , when there's such flaw in the token model, usually there's nothing you can do. The damage's already been done.

Author: daochemist
Content:
> you see, @DaoChemist , when there's such flaw in the token model, usually there's nothing you can do. The damage's already been done.
@Po Forget the solution for now, I'm just asking you a simple question, we both love Uniswap, saying there's an issue doesn't change that

Author: mr_po
Content: ok, that's fair. what misalignment do you see?

Author: mr_po
Content: who benefits? who suffers?

Author: daochemist
Content: There is a misalignment between farmers and hodlers. Farmers are (rightfully so, to grow the network) incentivized to farm $UNI, but they are not incentivized to hodl $UNI. As rational actors, many of them dump the $UNI they farm. This is obviously exarberated by short sellers, but only because they anticipate that farmers are rational actors and will dump. This is a misalignment with hodlers, who are subsidizing the farming only to get dumped on.

Author: mr_po
Content: ok, I can agree with that

Author: daochemist
Content: Cool! Now we can talk about solution(s). Because you could make the case that hodlers should just become farmers, but you would be making the case that there is no reason to hodl, which to me is a problem.

Author: mr_po
Content: but the problem lies in the fact that farmers are overincenitvized in my opinion

Author: daochemist
Content:
> but the problem lies in the fact that farmers are overincenitvized in my opinion
@Po Yes, but I think the team did that because they want to grow the network, the more people hodl $UNI the more decentralized the governance becomes, in theory.

Author: daochemist
Content: So if we want to keep that goal of further decentralizing governance, then rather than removing the incentive to farm, we need to add the incentive to hold

Author: mr_po
Content: another way to view the same problem though would be. That there are early buyers, and their interests are suffering from LPs and all the initial airdrop receivers

Author: daochemist
Content: Also, I admit to some bias, as far as I can see in economics, positive incentives are better reinforcing behaviors than negative incentives (i.e punishments). I don't believe in a token without a value capture mechanism. To me, a token is value capture. That's my view on things, we can disagree on the solutions, but it's important we have a consensus on the problem. So that's good.

Author: mr_po
Content: I view LP program as part of initial distribution that includes LP + airdrop

Author: mr_po
Content: so the point 0 will be after it ends

Content: The good thing about all of this is that decisions are made by UNI holders

Author: chrisblec
Content: I appreciate your passion, but you cannot simply say "all of the respondents were lying" and therefore the data is invalid. As I said, I was using the best tool I had available. Dharma, etc have much better access to these users than I do, and I invite them to invalidate this data.

Author: chrisblec
Content: If you are trying to make the case that because I don't have any possible definitive way to get this data, therefore I should simply ignore this most critical problem with the proposal, then I totally disagree.

Author: chrisblec
Content: I'm not a paid researcher for UNI governance, nor do I care to be. I'm just a user who wants decisions to be made on real data.

Content:
@DaoChemist I would like to address the mentality "holders are hurting" that is being used as an argument against the airdrop somewhat commonly. 
Holders are not hurting, they hold. As a holder is not intending to sell anytime soon, price fluctuations don't hurt him/her
The only ones who's hurting when the price goes down are sellers who wish they've sold earlier.
These sellers comprise of a) people who got their UNI for free b) people who made short term speculative investments when UNI launched

Author: judgentium#1709
Content: gday all.. is this the right place to share ideas for proposals, improve the platform etc..? I know about the thresholds in order to raise a proposal

Author: daochemist
Content:
> @d-dog.eth when we talk about people who bought into the project, we talk about present investors. I agree that their interests should be cared about. 
> There is a difference between present investors and traders, though. 
> Investors are ok with freezing the liquidity and participating in the network's growth. Short term traders participate in zero zum games that don't create value
@Po there is a difference between price action and token model. A token is designed to align the interest of the actors that make up a community. Self-interest/greed is not a bad thing, when it is aligned with the self-interests of the other actors that make up a community or network. You want to say it's okay for investors to subsidize farmers and other actors. But so far in crypto, the largest set of actors in any projects are hodlers. It's one thing if the price action is down for market reason, but this is not the case. The token model is punishing holders and rewarding farmers that dump on hodlers. Do you not see the difference?

Author: mr_po
Content:
> gday all.. is this the right place to share ideas for proposals, improve the platform etc..? I know about the thresholds in order to raise a proposal
@judgentium the best way to share your ideas is to create a topic on the forum in proposal discussion part: https://gov.uniswap.org/c/proposal-discussion/5 . You can still do it here preliminary, though, but a lot less people will be able to participate

Author: mr_po
Content:
> The token model is punishing holders and rewarding farmers that dump on hodlers. Do you not see the difference?
@DaoChemist the token model disproportionately rewards farmers during the first two months of UNI existence.
The token model also disproportionately rewards past users compared to present and future users. And compared to buyers too.
I see no problem with that, it is a distribution mechanism first and foremost, and it's certainly not a bad one in my opinion

Author: mr_po
Content: you have to start somewhere

> The token model also disproportionately rewards past users compared to present and future users. And compared to buyers too.

@Po You're dancing around the topic. "Disproportionately rewards" doesn't reflect what is actually happening. Hodlers are subsiziding farmers. That's what happening. They are also asked to subsidize airdrops on top of that. You see no problem maybe because you are farming?

Author: daochemist
Content: It's a strange thing to have a token model with no incentive to hodl. We've had 3-4 years of experimenting with token economics, with incentives, we know more or less what incentivize a set of actors, and what doesn't. $UNI doesn't have a reason to hodl. if you don't believe me, that's fine, but the market is seeing the same thing. So, at some point we have to acknowledge data and market feedback. Every week the same thing happened, what is the purpose of denial?

Author: daochemist
Content: Uniswap is a great project. $UNI has a flawed token model. Most likely it was released prematurely as a response to $SUSHI. Do you disagree?

Author: daochemist
Content:
> that most of the market feedback you're talking about is explained by boom & bust cycles
@Po So that's the real crux of your disagreement. Ok, so we can get to the bottom of that.

Author: daochemist
Content: Deep down, you think or feel that $UNI price action can be explain by market events, or early distribution, airdrops, or natural boom and bust, as your say

Author: mr_po
Content: most of newly launched projects enter the price depreciation mode, Ethereum included

Author: daochemist
Content: that's where we fundamentally see things differently. I get that

Author: daochemist
Content: The difference between $UNI and other projects that seem to have a similar graph is that $UNI is unique in that it is regularly the worst performing asset in the top 100 and that its graph doesn't have upward trends, only downward trends and sideway actions. If you look closely at the ETH graph, you won't see that.

Author: daochemist
Content: My point I was making yesterday, is if the price action was based on the actions of a set of actors, then the pattern should break, you should be able to point to an upward trend somewhere on the graph. The fact that you can't means there's something at play that more fundamental that regular market price action.

Author: daochemist
Content: If you see the same pattern repeat over an extended period of time, the explanation cannot be speculation, events, or market related, it has to be something inherent to the asset, i.e there's something about the asset itself that must be the cause. In the case of a token, that points to the token model.

Author: mr_po
Content: the problem is, 1.5  months is not an extended period of time

Author: daochemist
Content:
> the problem is, 1.5  months is not an extended period of time
@Po that's an arbitrary claim. If you can recognize trends, and those trends repeat over and over again, that's a pattern. That pattern repeats every week, the market is giving you plenty of feedback. You don't need years to acknowledge that feedback.

Author: daochemist
Content: Think outside of crypto, you're looking at a stock, and the stock dumps by 20% every week.

Author: daochemist
Content: that's not a pattern that there is something going on?

Author: daochemist
Content: You need 6 months to a year of seeing this before coming to a conclusion that something is going on?

Author: mr_po
Content: I'm afraid there's nothing substantial I can add to the discussion at this point, our approaches to the weight we give to market signals clearly differ, and that's ok

Author: daochemist
Content:
> I'm afraid there's nothing substantial I can add to the discussion at this point, our approaches to the weight we give to market signals clearly differ, and that's ok
@Po It appears that way. Again, I mean no disrespect, we both believe in Uniswap, but it's dangerous not to accept feedback. Price is the most decentralized feedback mechanism, the market is our friend, not some casino for short term gamblers.

Content: Just want to say that this last proposal had participation rate of 48.53% (and 16.59% of delegates with >0 UNI) — as governance participants, we **must** endeavor to improve these statistics. This means ensuring that any pools or staking instruments allow for pooled or staked UNI to be utilized for its intended purpose, that we must push to reform norms around delegate participation to encourage active voting in place of abstention, and that we must continue to encourage UNI holders to delegate their UNI. Looking forward to the next phase in Uniswap governance, and I'll see you all around 👋

Author: noodles#3657
Content:
Hi, so I think UNI's delegation abilities are really neat ok_hand but there are two limitations I've noticed:

1) Presently you can delegate 100% of your balance to 1 address. 
2) A delegate cannot further delegate a portion of their votes to a new delegate. 

I want to create a proposal to update delegation with the ideas below:

1) Delegate less than 100% of your votes to an address
2) Delegate votes to more than 1 address
3) A delegate can further delegate their shares to someone else. 

I'm writing here to gauge the technical feasibility of any of the above (3) ideas. Any devs have any thoughts on this?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I don't think (1) or (2) is worth the effort.  It feels like something that would rarely be used.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: (3) would be cool, but it introduces complexities like circular delegates that have to be dealt with, and it could prove difficult to keep everything processed in constant time.

Author: kaibakker#3613
Content: 1 and 2 should be done by splitting the UNI

Author: noodles#3657
Content: I guess my counter to (1) or (2) would be analogizing vote delegation to the `Like Button` on social media. People may find multiple members of the community worthy of a like (or vote)

Author: noodles#3657
Content: Yup @kaibakker you could split up the votes into multipe addresses and then delegate, but that is really bad UX for a user I guess

Author: noodles#3657
Content: Also in regards to (3) wouldnt it just be the same as updating the original delegator. Like: `delegator = noodles` so update it to `delegator = micah` . I dont see where the circular problen arises?

Author: noodles#3657
Content: (I may he missing some code specifics here)

Author: kaibakker#3613
Content: My second argument is that splitting up your votes is not functional, as voting is an all or nothing game. Imagine splitting votes 50/50. There are 2 possible scenarios: they both voted the same way, here you have effectively lowered changes of the proposal passing. In the other scenario both delegates vote the same, same outcome as when you would have voted 100% on 1.

Author: noodles#3657
Content:
@kaibakker hmmm i see what you mean but thats to say people only delegate votes on the basis of a single proposal. I think people delegate votes  based on reputation.

For instance, I may want to delegate my votes to Hayden (Uniswap) and SBF (FTX, Serum) despite the fact that they fundamentally disagree on a lot of things (and both would likely vote against each other)

Author: noodles#3657
Content: The case I mentioned above would be true for a lot of people in this community. Check the overlap of twitter followers for Hayden + SBF

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
> are removed within the silo of the treasury
Buy and burn burns tokens from circulating supply, not the treasury.

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
Imagine the system gets 100 USD worth of fees.  It can do one of two things with those fees:
1. Buy UNI tokens off the open market and then burn those purchased tokens.
2. Distribute 100 USD to all token holders proportionate to each of their UNI holdings.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: In both cases, 100 USD is being distributed.  In (1) the 100 USD reduces the market cap of UNI by 100 USD, which proportionately increases everyone's per-token value since the value proposition has not changed at all from this transaction.  In (2) the 100 USD is distributed to individual users, so everyone proportionately gained the same 100 USD, just in a different form.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Another way to think about it: (1) gives everyone unrealized gains and (2) gives everyone realized gains.

Author: Deleted User
Content: Makes sense with unrealized gains and realized. How would the timing of this buy back and burn work? I assume it would have to happen all at one time (block x) for simplicity. If this 100 USD is distributed to everyone, then these funds can be used to purchase any token by that individual user, at any specific time after receiving from block x. The economic impact in this case is different in how the market reacts to this fee's use; buying and burning vs distributing out. I would also say buying and burning is not much different than traditional companies doing a stock buy back, while distributing out can be seen as dividends to investors. Dividend distributions and stock buybacks are entirely different in how the market reacts to these fund uses.

Author: hodldwon
Content:
I think UNI fees should mimic Harvest.Finance's model of market-buy and distribute.

That is fees are used to buy UNI from the ETH:UNI pool and the UNI purchased is distributed to those users LPing in the UNI pool.

So if someone is buying USDC with ETH, the 0.05% of ETH paid in fee goes and buys UNI which then goes to UNI:ETH LPs.

If someone buys USDT with USDC, then the 0.05% fee of USDC routes through ETH and buys UNI.

The purchases/distributions can also be batched; accumulating in pools until some threshold ($500?), or high price-impact trades (1% PI?) or some time limit is hit (daily?, weekly?).

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
> Makes sense with unrealized gains and realized. How would the timing of this buy back and burn work? I assume it would have to happen all at one time (block x) for simplicity. If this 100 USD is distributed to everyone, then these funds can be used to purchase any token by that individual user, at any specific time after receiving from block x. The economic impact in this case is different in how the market reacts to this fee's use; buying and burning vs distributing out. I would also say buying and burning is not much different than traditional companies doing a stock buy back, while distributing out can be seen as dividends to investors. Dividend distributions and stock buybacks are entirely different in how the market reacts to these fund uses.
@Deleted User The specifics of implementing a buy and burn in Uniswap is complicated, but the best solution I have seen is auctioning off rights to all fees (which are in a bunch of different tokens) and winners get rights to withdraw their share of all fee tokens anytime within a 24 hour window or something.

Author: hodldwon
Content:
It only pays the single UNI:ETH Pool. It would not pay to any other LP pools.

Then additionally (a split of fees) or alternatively (all fees), the UNI puchased from the ETH:UNI pool from sold fee tokens can be given as yield to locked UNI.

Further still Locked UNI could be in tranches with instant enter/exit, 1 month lock, or 1 year lock. The longer the lockup the higher the share of UNI yield.

80% of fees go to UNI locked for 1 year.
15% of fees to UNI locked for 1 month
5% of fees for instant entry/exit staked UNI.

For example. Time value of money being a critical piece of the puzzle.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: We cannot control how fees come in.  They will come in the form of a million different tokens.

Author: hodldwon
Content:
I am aware, why's that a problem? They'll all be routed to the same address and accumulate, yes?

And from there they can be sold and UNI purchased? Using *some* mechanism... Be it market buys or auctions as you suggested before?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: "some mechanism" is a very hard problem.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The only reasonable solution I have seen (I have thought quite a bit about it and spoken with several experts on the subject) is to auction off time limited rights to all assets in the pool.  You can do a uniform price multiunit auction so you don't need a single large buyer.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: This auction would be denominated in UNI and the proceeds burned.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: All other solutions I have seen proposed so far have some problem that makes them way more complicated than they seem at first.

Author: Deleted User
Content: could you go more into detail on how this auction works (i.e. what exactly does time limited rights to the assets mean)? What stops only a few from benefitting from this auction (if I am a small inactive HODLer do I lose out to more active auction participants)?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Imagine that some contract owns a million different tokens (the fee recipient contract).  Users would participate in a descending uniform price multi-unit auction.  The winners would all receive a share of rights to all of the tokens that contract owns for the next 24 hours.  Each user could submit one or more transactions at any time during that period to withdraw their share of any individual token of the million tokens.  Upon doing so, they would receive their proportionate share of those tokens.  Any unclaimed tokens after the withdraw window ends would remain in the contract until the next auction.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: This strategy allows individual auction participants to decide which tokens are actually worth withdrawing, and the auction will effectively price in the cost of withdrawing each asset and the value of all of the assets combined.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: What is nice about this strategy is that we don't have to deal with the fact that many tokens are worthless, and many will generate fees that are too small to be worth withdrawing (gas costs are too high).

Author: sky.cactus
Content: It also deals well with fluctuating gas prices as it is up to individual auction participants to deal with gas price fluctuations.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: By having the auction denominated in UNI and the UNI then burned, UNI holders benefit due to a reduction in circulating and total supply in the same way that a stock buyback benefits all stock holders similarly to how dividends benefit all stock holders.  However, with a buy and burn mechanic like this we don't have to solve the relatively hard problem of distributing some other currency (e.g., ETH) to all UNI holders.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: UNI buy and burn is also incredibly gas efficient compared to distribution of fees in some other token like ETH since you have a single burn transaction rather than having 100,000 individual withdraw transactions.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: @Deleted User

Author: sky.cactus
Content: For small holders buy & burn is especially nice because you benefit from the fees without having to spend any gas.  This is far more impactful to small holders than large since for large holders the fees will be lost in the noise.

No, not at all.  The auction participants would most likely *not* be Uniswap holders.  They would probably buy UNI off the open market just prior to the auction or as part of their bid with the sole intent of using it to bid on the fees.

Author: teemulau#7395
Content:
https://www.placeholder.vc/blog/2020/9/17/stop-burning-tokens-buyback-and-make-instead

I sincerely hope that UNI governance does not vote for a buyback&burn model when the 0.05% fee is implemented. I think you shouldn't even have an opinion on the topic unless you've read and internalised the above blog post. 

I think simply "stablecoins as dividends" works really well in the long run, and I think Curve chose the right path regarding this. This way people get the cash flow from owning CRV (by locking to veCRV), but they freely choose what to do with that cash flow, whether the compound it back to more veCRV, or to do something else.

Buyback&burn first forces you to accept that more UNI is bought with the 0.05% cash flow, and then it would be simply burnt. It can hurt the long-term capitalisation and growth of Uniswap as proposed in the blog post, if done this way. 

I'm surprised that the tentative consensus in the Uniswap community seems to be towards a buyback&burn model. It would be a mistake in my opinion. 

Imagine buying stocks that are supposed to pay dividends, then the company never pays dividends but rather always automatically buybacks shares, and then *the company treasury would always burn those shares*. Madness.

Author: teemulau#7395
Content: So pls no token burns.

Author: kaibakker#3613

Author: hodldwon
Content:
100% against buy back and burn. It is working poorly for MakerDAO.

UNI should have a yield and it should be paid to active participants will to provide liquidity in an ETH:UNI pool so other users can enter/exit UNI with low price impact.

AND it should be paid in part OR fully to users willing to timelock UNI in a staking contract.

Author: alex_0955
Content:
> 
> @teemulau this is actually a pretty common practice.  It has some nice tax incentives for shareholders compared to dividends because the gains are unrealized and taxed as capital gains (long term for many).
> @Micah A few points, I don't think the discussion surround the fee switch should be dictated by which of the two paths are taxable events and which aren't, but instead which incentivizes holding onto UNI and better rewards active participants.  Following the second line, I would argue that a Synthetix style staking mechanism that distributes trading fees is way better at encouraging holding UNI than a burn mechanism. Using BNB as an example there was a ton of analysis done a year ago about how the Burn was a tradable event, people buying before and selling. We can argue the nuances about how BNB doesn't buy on the open market leading to a buyer of last resort, but that still doesn't change my point of it not incentivizing holding the token.  Overall both options would make UNI a better token than it currently is, but I would waaaaaay rather see UNI being a productive CF producing asset for token holders than just a deflationary asset.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: IMO, the only reason one should hold UNI is for the promise of future fees.  I also personally don't really care about short term trickery and techniques to give temporary boosts to UNI price.  I care about the long term viability of UNI being able to extract future fees.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The thing that most positively impacts future price is ensuring that UNI holders receive 0.05% distributed in a way that is as low cost, simple, and reliable as possible.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Buy & Burn via bulk auction is the only proposal I have seen so far that achieves all of that.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The biggest risk is people disagreeing on the mechanism by which to turn on the fee switch.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: For example, I'll vote against anything that isn't secure, and some people may vote against anything that isn't their preferred distribution mechanism.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I have seen a *lot* of people propose distribution schemes that are insecure.

Author: ivglavas#7263
Content:
> To decide how the 0.05% fee is distributed.
@Micah what is your view as best solution for this? IMO there are three possibilities:
1. 0.05% goes proportionally from all markets to token holders as assets they can claim
2. 0.05% goes to Vault and Uniswap becomes not only DEX but DEF as well (some sort of decentralized fund)
3. 0.05% used for buyback and burn UNI tokens (eg. using Gnosis DutchX auction is best option IMO)

Is there any other option what to do with 0.05% beside leave everything as is now..?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: @ivglavas I advocate for a buy and burn,mthough Gnosis Dutch won't work in this case.  (2) doesn't align with why people value UNI, and (1) is way too complicated to implement.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: @d-dog.eth UNI governance gets to decide UNI governance and where the 0.05% fee goes.  That is the line.  😄

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Where "UNI governance" includes "what to do with all of the extra UNI that governance controls".

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Most of it sacrifices censorship resistance.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: People are just finding clever ways to build centralized apps that look kind of like decentralized apps to the layman.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: If you just build a centralized app things get *way* faster and cheaper... but also censorable.

Author: _allo
Content: So OVM is centralized ?

Author: _allo
Content: I know there are tradeoffs but I didn't know these solution sacrificed decentralization that much

Author: _allo
Content: I gtg , nice discussion ! Way better than in #🦄│speculation  hahah

Author: sky.cactus
Content: @allô Optimistic rollups that only solve for gas costs, not for speed, generally don't sacrifice either data availability or censorship resistance.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: If they make claims about speed improvements, they are most likely sacrificing either censorship resistance or data availability.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Data availability issues can turn into censorship.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Essentially, the sacrifice free L2 still puts all transactions on Ethereum, it just moves execution and state off chain, which is where you can get big gains in gas cost reduction for some applications.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Since transactions are still on Ethereum, this means that you still have to wait for an Ethereum block to mine, and then blocks on top of it for "confirmation".

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Transactions being smaller (less gas) *does* help though because you can fit more in a block (higher throughput).

Author: opencom#9437
Content: So is there any proposals being worked on for direct staking of UNI?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: It is heavily debated whether we (UNI holders) want more staking or not.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The immediate threat of bleeding liquidity to silly clones like SushiSwap has been largely dealt with, and we retain the ability to turn on liquidity mining at any time should they spring back up in sufficient force.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: We don't necessarily need to continue diluting ourselves needlessly.

Author: opencom#9437
Content: Please clarify, what does it mean to not necessarily need to continue diluting the UNI "price needlessly". Why was it necessary and why would it this time be needless, in your view? I took the liberty to change a few words, but please call a spade a spade.

Author: opencom#9437
Content: Did we have staking? The LP for you are a form of staking?

Author: opencom#9437
Content: Honestly just a bit in the dark, probably due to my ignorance.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: UNI liquidity mining specifically addresses the perceived threat of third party Uniswap clones pulling liquidity off of Uniswap.  By offering a similar scheme, Uniswap was able to pull that liquidity back.  Personally, I don't think it was necessary but many people disagree with this.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Governance is sitting on a big pile of UNI and they need to (eventually) decide what to do with it.  One option is to continue funding liquidity mining, another would be to burn it, another would be to distribute it to existing non-dev UNI holders, another would be to buy goods/services with it.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Anything other than burning or distributing to existing UNI holders is diluting existing holders, since self distribution and burning are on the table.

Author: opencom#9437
Content: Interesting, thanks! Agree that Buy Back & Burn is an inflationary measure, but is it enough? Do you think staking is also an option to dry-up circulating (speculative) CEX supply?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I don't think it is necessary.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Centralized exchanges will continue to be hacked, require KYC, and be shutdown and siezed by governments around the world while Uniswap keeps chugging along with more and more assets available without any censorship or centralized risks.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Basically, I suspect that CEXs will simply die off naturally with time, no need for us to do anything hasty about it.  Just keep providing a high quality user experience.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: As long as UNI has speculative value, people will trade it.  We should do our best to provide a high quality customer experience and encourage people to use Uniswap instead of trusting centralized exchanges with a history of hurting customers.

Author: opencom#9437
Content: OK, interesting. BUT i think they are getting begger as BTC supply drops.  An idea is that UNI be traded as a stable coin of DEFI. Another, using UNI as a lending platform token? What do people think?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: UNI is a promise of future fees, not a stable coin.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Stable coins require a lot of very specific engineering, none of which UNI has.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: UNI is also just a token, not a platform.  Uniswap is a platform, but governance is not in control of development direction.

Author: opencom#9437
Content: Yeah, a promise of DEX fees. UNI is a governance token which means dynamic engineering is possible. I didn't mean a stable FIAT coin. I meant a stable DEX coin based on DEX metrics. You may have missed the point.

Content: Has anyone researched the Curve DAO governance model? Their inflation scheduale is the worse out of all of the big DEFI tokens, but their staking/governance format I believe is the best.

Content: In order to collect rewards LPs must stake UNI and depending on how long they lock it for the weight is different.

Author: rpnilo.gg
Content:
A simple buy back and burn does not do enough to attract buyers or governance participants, the best example is MakerDao. One can argue thats the most important protocol in DEFI and its performance has been the worse out of group. 

Another great example is new Aave tokenomics. Staking of the governance tokens gives a reason for people to BUY/HOLD the token and participate in governance.

The fact that mining is about to end and there's no proposals to include new pools is evidence that the incentives for governance are not baked in. Author: Cr3ateD#0001
Content:
I'm not sure why there's so much panic around rewards expiring. If their expiry significantly weakens the system then governance will quickly switch it back on in some form.

LPs move their coins with effectively zero cost in both time and money. Let's act once we have the data and can optimize UNI rewards.

I also think UNI rewards should be autonomous and not via slow governance. Having hundreds of people spend hours debating rewards is brutally inefficient.

Curve has solved this to some extent and The Graph is doing something similar but with incentives that ensure stakers vote honestly.

I don't think many decisions need to be made to be honest, but the decisions that do need making would benefit from being made quickly.

Author: Cr3ateD#0001
Content:
- UNI holders create a board of directors (let's say, 7 people)
- snapshot.page polls that reach some level of quorum go to the board
- Board makes decisions and then it gets ratified onchain

There is a reason we don't have 5,000 member parliaments as you say. Ethereum doesn't suddenly fix age-old governance problems because we gather on the internet instead of in a building.

Author: Cr3ateD#0001
Content:
So on the subject of rewards, this is how it would look:

- snapshot.page yes/no poll gets created for "Should UNI reward distribution be restarted?"
- if "yes" reaches some quorum, it goes to the board
- board makes a decision

Author: Cr3ateD#0001
Content:
> @🐧Hiturunk🐧- Penguin Party perhaps you could counter my point by explaining what the Penguin Party are doing to help relieve the governance deadlock.
btw, all I am suggesting is that vote delegation has two facets:

1. allows the delegatee to vote on behalf of the delegator (as it is currently)
2. allows the delagatee to discuss decisions with other top delegated members in an open channel which is then put back to vote

This means that UNI holders still have to vote. But each time we do a call, the board actually comes to decisions about what to put forward to the rest of us.

Author: Cr3ateD#0001
Content:
____
Take yesterday's call as an example:

An agenda of topics are led by a chair who puts them to the board to answer.

The board debates; hears from community members (arguments for/against, presentations etc) and so on.

After, the board make decisions about anything that was pressing and put those decisions to a snapshot.page vote.

UNI holders can then dismiss or accept those decisions.

Author: Cr3ateD#0001
Content:
So yesterday; what likely would have happened would have been a snapshot.page poll that went live shortly after with Robert Leshner's proposal for ETH/USDC and ETH/WBTC rewards.

Decentralized governance then kicks in and we all vote.

Author: mr_po

Author: mr_po

Author: Cr3ateD#0001
Content:
soft governance informs those board meetings; helps us to establish pros/cons and put forward arguments for/against.

These then get heard by a board that the community respects (we voted them in) and then the outcomes can then once again go through the checks and balances of a UNI token holder vote.

Author: Cr3ateD#0001
Content:
By doing it in a formalized way, we can actually rally around ideas.

Yesterday, Robert threw out that idea and then everything has gone quiet. No one knows what to do. How do we get people participating when there is no clear process or expectation.

Content:
> @Tritium agree with your sentiment here. It's great that we're all so passionate about Uniswap but we need to accept that thousands of people having an equally valid voice and opinion is going to create enormous gridlock.
> 
> I imagine over time people will begin to just establish their own mental model of a "board of directors". Voices will begin to quiet and the more dedicated and trusted members come forward.
> 
> But this could take months and would be passive. I would much rather see an active effort to skip that period and just start firing on a handful of important decisions.
@Cr3ateD Sounds like American Politiics.

Author: Cr3ateD#0001
Content:
> How can it not stay standstill if one of the bigger and more reputable delegates doesn't use the procedures?

There is no procedure. And we can't expect Robert to come up with it. If we all agree on a procedure that actually ensures decisions are made (whether it's to keep the status quo or otherwise), we can actually rally voters.

Our communication and process is all over the place. Which is fine and to be expected. But needs addressing

Author: Cr3ateD#0001
Content:
"Decentralized Autonomous Organization" 

To me that describes the end state. It certainly does not describe the current state.

We are on a journey. We don't suddenly solve centuries old governance by handing out votes across the internet. We have to crawl before we can run.

The technology will get there eventually, but I fear that idealism will swiftly be replaced by pragmatism (and so we better start thinking pragmatically)

Author: mr_po
Content: While we can potentially create an entity on top of Uniswap where the power is distributed much more evenly than in plutocratic systems. And this entity could solve a lot of smaller scale questions - that you wish the board of directors would solve

Author: sky.cactus
Content: As an Austrian economist, I'm against trying to control the UNI price.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I have a personal valuation of UNI that is projected out over a very long time horizon (e.g., decades) and if UNI drops below that price sufficiently I may consider buying more.  Otherwise, I don't care what the price is.

Author: opencom#9437
Content:
> As an Austrian economist, I'm against trying to control the UNI price.
@Micah Your not a CEX, fortunately. But what about the  putting in place measures to prevent CEXs sfrom accumulating all the UNI, as  a governance issue? From that perspective... Is that important to you?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I don't care if CEXs accumulate UNI, I don't really care *who* accumulates UNI really.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: If it were entirely up to me I would probably choose to castrate governance entirely so it cannot do much of anything.  Specifically, I would enable a mechanism for fee distribution to UNI holders that cannot be changed.  That way I don't have to care if some whale accumulates all of the UNI, they can't take away my returns.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Trying to control *who* captures governance isn't addressing the core problem, which is that there is value to capturing governance.

Author: opencom#9437
Content:
The DAO as I see it is very much integral to DEFI! 
Economic variables change and Governence required as a means to gravitate
 humans to "Open Developement" through DEFI, otherwise your locked  into something else.

Author: opencom#9437
Content: We can agree to disagree

Author: hiturunk
Content:
> Trying to control *who* captures governance isn't addressing the core problem, which is that there is value to capturing governance.
@Micah

Author: hiturunk
Content: ^ This is some very deep food for thought about plutocratic republics.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: It is basically my argument against all governments.  😬

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Giving someone power is the problem, since you cannot forever control who has that power.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Are you familiar with stationary bandit theory?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Better to just not give up the power in the first place.

Author: hiturunk
Content: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mancur_Olson

Author: hiturunk
Content: "Olson argued that under anarchy, a "roving bandit" only has the incentive to steal and destroy, whilst a "stationary bandit"—a tyrant—has an incentive to encourage some degree of economic success as he expects to remain in power long enough to benefit from that success. A stationary bandit thereby begins to take on the governmental function of protecting citizens and their property against roving bandits. In the move from roving to stationary bandits, Olson sees the seeds of civilization, paving the way, eventually for democracy, which by giving power to those who align with the wishes of the population, improves incentives for good government."

Author: hiturunk
Content: Hm, It seems to me that following his model, Uniswap and other Web3 governance are still in roving bandit phase.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Eventually stationary bandits will form [protocol delegates]

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The difference is that we can simply prevent bandits via code.  There are no bandits to start with, so we need not introduce a stationary bandit.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Those delegates then form alliances and we move more towards actual egalitarian republicanism

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Also, the above assumes that the stationary bandit has a sufficiently long time horizon.  This isn't true in many modern governments where elections are very regular.

Author: hiturunk
Content:
> The difference is that we can simply prevent bandits via code.  There are no bandits to start with, so we need not introduce a stationary bandit.
@Micah I don't think bandit necessarily means something bad, just roving hunter-gatherer type governance, a free-for-all

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Based on that quote, I suspect the author considers banditry bad.  🙂

Author: hiturunk
Content:
> Based on that quote, I suspect the author considers banditry bad.  🙂
@Micah Uh - necessary evil of sociological development I think is his take?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: It is a very pragmatic yet negative view of governments as an inevitable outcome that one would like to avoid but cannot.

Author: hiturunk
Content: I mean - at face value, yeah, marauding is bad - In the context of sociological development: a phase

Author: hiturunk
Content:
> It is a very pragmatic yet negative view of governments as an inevitable outcome that one would like to avoid but cannot.
@Micah I can agree. It's just one model.

Author: hiturunk
Content: I think it is also interesting food for thought. Models are not always correct, and they surely say something of their authors' biases.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Ideally, there would be no bandits, and thus no need for government.  However, since there are bandits, governments *will* develop over time.  Thus, what can we do to minimize the negative impact of banditry given the above?

Author: hiturunk
Content: ^ See? Exactly 😄 It's interesting!

Author: sky.cactus
Content: My solution to the problem is to ensure that the government has the bare minimum amount of power and resources required to fend off other bandits, but no more.

Author: hiturunk
Content:
> My solution to the problem is to ensure that the government has the bare minimum amount of power and resources required to fend off other bandits, but no more.
@Micah I can get behind small government.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: In the case of Uniswap governance, since we can write code that cannot be changed later, that power can be made to be *very* small (i.e., nearly non-existent).

Author: hiturunk
Content: ^ Agreed. A lot of things are already hardcoded constants.

Author: hiturunk
Content: [such as fee amounts]

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I would like to see the UNI fee distribution strategy permanently locked as well.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: That is, once we turn it on we throw away the key.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Really? No flexibility?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: As long as that flexibility exists, there will be opportunity for an attacker to seize that opportunity.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Not criticizing, just curious of the idea.

Author: hiturunk
Content:
> As long as that flexibility exists, there will be opportunity for an attacker to seize that opportunity.
@Micah This is true. Having it locked in code is relevant to our trustless values.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I like flexibility as much as the next person, but it means there is power to be had, and where there is power to be had there will be people who seek to capture that power for themselves.

Author: hiturunk
Content: I can agree fully.

Author: hiturunk
Content: [even if I do think flexibility has other advantages]

Author: hiturunk
Content: Are governments endemically corruptible by nature, or does republican democracy work? A question for the ages..

Author: hiturunk
Content: I'd say your argument has more weight: The examples throughout history are of democracy failing despite the best attempts of idealists.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Which doesn't stop me from being an idealist - but it does make me consider that you may be right and locking the fee schedule could be extremely valuable.

Author: hiturunk
Content: [even if it meant throwing away a lot of flexibility of Uniswap as an organization]

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
> Are governments endemically corruptible by nature, or does republican democracy work? A question for the ages..
@🐧Hiturunk🐧- Penguin Party Where there is transferable power, it can eventually be captured.

Author: hiturunk
Content: I would go so far as to say: given a long enough timeline - it *will* be captured.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Mathematically improbable for it not to be.

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
The two mitigations are:
1. Make power non-transferable.  This is impossible in many cases, very hard in others, easy in others.
2. Make the cost of power transfer very high.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: By making the cost of power transfer high relative to the amount of power gained it can take away a lot of the incentive to capture the power in the first place.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: If you can get to a point where the cost to capture power is higher than the benefits that power brings you have a good system.

Author: hiturunk
Content:
> If you can get to a point where the cost to capture power is higher than the benefits that power brings you have a good system.
> 
Hmm.

Author: hiturunk
Content: Double-spending consensus seems relevant here.

Author: hiturunk
Content: I think you are probably right, the best thing to do is lock the fee schedule so it's the same deal going forward and it just does what it does - there's no changing it and co-opting the fees.

Author: hiturunk
Content: [capturing the real monetary value of Uniswap]

Author: sky.cactus
Content: FWIW, I already have a new preference for fee distribution mechanics but it can't be implemented in Uniswap because of the way UNI governance was setup originally.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: So I totally appreciate the frustration of preventing change.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Despite that, I still think it is worth it.  We can always try to have the new system take over in Uniswap v3.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: So it isn't truly forever.

Author: hiturunk
Content: : P

Author: hiturunk
Content: I wish we had more info about the mechanics of v3.

Author: seb_ethmonk
Content: I am reviewing previous posts etc regarding the liquidity mining; I will try to post a more precise post but I think liquidity mining is a good way to decentralize and continue distributing the protocol; I wonder how the community would feel it we (in the vein of farming) had Seasons; every three months we rotate the liquidity pools earning UNI based on community need, market demand etc. I do think we need to probably give lowering the quorum down a bit to allow for more actionable things happening (let me add I also agree that we shouldn't rely on UNI for liquidity mining long long term)

Author: _allo
Content:
> What would the downside of changing one of the pools to UNI-ETH? What are @Seb -Eth Monk-, myself and many others from Twitter and the community call missing here??
@DKrilla(Cielo.Finance) downside is : LPers can't vote, so it hurts the voting system (in a context where we have a hard time getting quorum)... I think this is the only bad aspect of this proposal, but it's a huge one imo

Content:
right now, in V2, impermanent loss is something a lot of LPers or would-be LPers fear. we don't know a lot about IL, uniswap LPing is still being researched as an investing strategy.
now, until V3 comes with solutions to mitigate IL (or better control it), it's probably a good idea to incentivise liquidity.

Author: opencom#9437
Content:
> We need to stop bringing up printing more UNI as a way to solve all problems
@SWISH Those UNI have already been issued (printed as you say). The problem is that if LP providers dump their UNI as a way to increase APY, then it will be difficult to protect its value. We need some feedback mechanics between the UNI the whales dump and those that are/were held by a majority of wallets. Otherwise a cascade sell-off effect occurs which is what we experienced in the prior dump. The majority of holders or those who sold UNI are likely to be watchful of UNI governance, and this governance mechanism or something similar could be the ticket to a sustainable UNI price.

Author: vapur
Content:
The problem is, the 4% quorum requirement based on total supply of 1B is unworkable when 800M isn't even circulating. 

UNI needs to continue to be distributed or it'll just be a pet rock -- it doesn't earn fees and its too scarce to govern with as it stands.

Author: vapur
Content:
The long term goal should be:
1. allow UNI to be better used as a DAO token
2. Pass a vote to enable fee sharing to UNI holders.

Refusing to incentivise more LPs is just pointless at this stage. 

Any sustained long term growth would need to come from the fee share element, otherwise any price action will be based purely on speculation that it might one day be something other than a pet rock

Author: dkrillacielo.finance
Content:
> UNI liquidity mining is worse though.
@Micah Ah yeah, I feel the same way. I also feel that the incentives for Uniswap team and their main community people like Monet Supply are not 100% aligned with the "everday" UNI holders.  And that is fine. Incentives don't need to line up exactly, but we should be aware of it.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: @Po History and reason tells us that the UNI will flow into the hands of those who value it most, and out of the hands of those who value it least.  No matter how you try to control who gets the UNI to start, it will eventually flow in that fashion.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: You cannot vote with UNI used for liquidity mining, which is one of the major downsides to liquidity mining as it disincentivizes actually participating in governance.  All it does is just distributes UNI to existing UNI holders, but there are better ways to achieve that which don't require the UNI being locked up and not being able to be used for voting.

Author: mr_po
Content: @Micah oh, I wasn't referring to UNI/ETH pair. I was speaking about BTC and USD pairs. People who mine these pairs are able to participate in governance

Author: mr_po
Content: I do agree with your first statement, though

Author: mr_po
Content: but I appear to be making a different conclusion

Author: OatMan#0321
Content: @Po yes I see, because the UNI is not locked into the liquidity pair.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Ah, ignore the second statement then.

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
Given the first statement, liquidity mining only serves two purposes:
1. **Temporarily** increase the amount of liquidity on a particular pair.
2. Give away capital to people who **temporarily** help with (1).

Author: mr_po
Content:
> @Po No matter how you try to control who gets the UNI to start, it will eventually flow in that fashion.
@Micah Doesn't this statement lead to being agnostic about incentives? 
I think there is an important distinction to make, though - and it addresses "**eventually**". 
The way you try to control who gets UNI to start affects when and how this happens - and the final distribution of those supporters

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I care about the long term, and in the long term initial distribution is pretty inconsequential.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Long term here being years down the road.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I don't really care what the UNI distribution is this week, or this month, or even this year.

Author: mr_po
Content: as for the second conclusion, I have my doubts about **temporary **nature of the increased liquidity

Author: sky.cactus
Content: You are paying liquidity providers to show up.  Once you stop paying them, they'll stop showing up.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: You can't pay your carpenter for a week and then expect them to stick around and keep working for another week after that even though you stopped paying them.

Author: mr_po
Content: @Micah at this point, 56% of liquidity provision money have stayed with incentives ending. We'll gather more data in the coming weeks

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Is that after accounting for natural product growth, initial liquidity that was there before the UNI mining, etc.?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Perhaps Uniswap simply has grown over the past months.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: It is also a bull run, which often results in new capital allocations.

Author: mr_po
Content: I mean simply the money that decided to not withdraw from the lp mining contract so far

Author: mr_po
Content: seems like a decent metric to me

Author: mr_po
Content: it is the % of money deposited to liquidity mining program (earning 0%) / overall liquidity on Uniswap

Author: mr_po
Content:
> Given the first statement, liquidity mining only serves two purposes:
> 1. **Temporarily** increase the amount of liquidity on a particular pair.
> 2. Give away capital to people who **temporarily** help with (1).
@Micah **Temporarily ** here implies that there is no retention rate at all. I'm positive that there is retention rate. The question is how to guesstimate it better, what the boundaries of that possible retention rate are

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Oh, I think the above is because there is really no reason to with draw from LM if you don't plan on withdrawing from LP.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: All of those pools already had lots of liquidity before the LM program, plus as I mentioned there is likely natural Ethereum growth, and the UNI announcement generally got people interested in looking.

Author: mr_po
Content: valid point

Author: mr_po
Content: I'm currently looking at ETH/USDT data and I think there might be a metric we could use. It is the ratio of liquidity to volume. Or in other words: what is the weighted APY LPs need to stay in the pool. That ratio appears to be different before and after the program, but we need at least a week to pass to tell more accurately

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I will concede that there is *some* amount of memory in capital.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: It takes effort to move capital around, and so while I do believe that the capital attracted by LM will eventually disappear, that won't happen overnight.

Author: _allo
Content: It'd be nice if Gauntlet could do the math and show us 😅

Author: _allo
Content: Given the major $$$$ involved in UNI I have to say I'm surprised that we haven't seen any serious (data+math) analysis so far concerning the future of incentives

Author: _allo
Content: Although the 50% rate cut that's being proposed sounds very OK to me (while we figure out the future of the program with more data)

Author: mr_po
Content:
It sounds reasonable for me two due to two main reasons.
1) The initial liquidity program seems to overincentivize liquidity to the point where LPs profit from fees becomes negligible
2) There seems to be a split in the interests of the community. Part of it benefits from participation in LM program, part of it doesn't. 
50% seems like a good middleground for the 2 factions

Author: mr_po
sky.cactus
Content:
> What is the value in distributing UNI to existing holders?
@Po It increases the value of UNI voter shares at the expense of decreasing the relative value of developer/investor share.

Author: mr_po
Content: but any distribution does that

Author: sky.cactus
Content: It is a rational action for governance to take, and one that pretty much all governance in history has taken.  Once you acquire a small amount of power, use that power to acquire more power.

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
> but any distribution does that
@Po The goal is to enrich the voting population, not to enrich *someone else*.

Author: mr_po
Content: imo distributing UNI towards new valueable participants of the network (LPs, Users, Contributors) makes more sense while achieving the same increase in UNI voter shares

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
Voter 1: "Hey, there is a big pile of money over there, we should vote how to spend it."
Voter 2: "I vote to give it to us (the voters)."
All Other Voters: "That sounds like a great idea!"

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
> imo distributing UNI towards new valueable participants of the network (LPs, Users, Contributors)
One thing to keep in mind with all such suggestions is that anyone proposing such a suggestion is *probably* of the demographic they are suggesting to distribute more UNI to.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: If someone suggests, "we should give it to LPs", you can probably bet pretty safely that they are an LP, or are at least in a position to *become* an LP.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: This is effectively people voting to "give more money to me, less to other people" in a slightly more subtle way.  I say we just make it obvious and be honest about it if we are going to go down that road.

Author: mr_po
Content: Does your statement imply that if someone suggests to just distribute UNI towards UNI holders and noone else, it means that they just want to hold their UNI, commit no work for the protocol improvement and growth, and just receive the rent?

Author: mr_po
Content: when it comes to the demographics, I believe there some demographics to reward that bring more benefits to the protocol than others, it's not a zero-sum game

Author: mr_po
Content: the sum of the game depends on what demographics are being rewarded, in other words

Author: mr_po
Content: distributing all the UNI to all the current holders makes the distribution process as zero sum as it can be

Author: mr_po
Content: what I propose is to distribute the UNI supply towards actors who contribute to the growth of the protocol. The assumption here is that rewarding populations that increase the value of the protocol brings more long term value than rewarding passive holders

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
> Does your statement imply that if someone suggests to just distribute UNI towards UNI holders and noone else, it means that they just want to hold their UNI, commit no work for the protocol improvement and growth, and just receive the rent?
@Po I am not against rent in this context, personally.

Author: mr_po
Content: thus, the passive holders win more too in the long run

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The developers got a substantial share of UNI for their past work, and I think they deserve it.  They also gave some of that away to random people on the internet who may or may not deserve it, and that was their choice.

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
> what I propose is to distribute the UNI supply towards actors who contribute to the growth of the protocol. The assumption here is that rewarding populations that increase the value of the protocol brings more long term value than rewarding passive holders
@Po This is an honorable position to take, but I'm not sure it is realistic.  Deciding who is deserving of capital is a really hard problem, and it is made harder (arguably insurmountably harder) when that decision is distributed across a large volume of pseudo-anonymous participants.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Just look at any traditional government and the process for dividing up tax money.  Those aren't even pseudo-anonymous, and they still suffer massively from corruption and ineffectual spending.

Author: mr_po
Content: I think ineffectual spending is not a major issue at all. Corruption is, but internet space provides more transparency to prevent that

Author: mr_po
Content:
The concept I'm talking about could be viewed as akin to the staking mechanism.
When you stake in PoS, you provide work to improve the network's security and thus increase your share of the network's supply at the expense of the non-stakers. These non-stakers still benefit from the work you're doing, though.
Similar to this, in Uniswap, there are active roles that foster the growth of the protocol.

Author: mr_po
Content: But there is no staking, as 'staking' UNI does not imply any work

Author: mr_po
Content: I can't recall a successful protocol that would just distribute new supply towards its holders, this model doesn't make any sense to me - as it theoretically just lowers the price.

Author: m4lkm4lk
Content:
> I can't recall a successful protocol that would just distribute new supply towards its holders, this model doesn't make any sense to me - as it theoretically just lowers the price.
@Po Honestly this whole debate could have been avoided by implementing a vesting program similar to SNX to prevent UNI holders from immediately dumping their coins, but instead the coins are subject to a timelock, or even better, a smart contract trigger that kicks in when total exchange volume reaches a certain level. Giving away free coins just leads to an initial dump and the coins will inevitably be purchased at a depressed price by whales and institutions. So there goes our decentralized dreams.

Author: mr_po
Content: @m4lkm4lk well if the coins are bought at depressed prices by different whales and institutions than the ones that already own it, the supply of the coin gets decentralized.

Author: mr_po
Content: the more decentralized the supply of the coin (i.e. it is owned by 100 whales instead of 10 whales), the better store of value capacity it possesses

Author: m4lkm4lk
Content: True, but I guess if the idea is to 'decentralize' ownership amongst retail holders and little guys, not necessarily VCs and whale miners, then allowing the coin to be dumped and effectively manipulated down on Binance because of low liquidity defeats that purpose. But I don't argue that it is still decentralization. I can't even argue that ownership by institutions and whales is necessarily a bad thing. Although if that was the purpose, what was the point of the airdrop to begin with, why not skip all of that and close of distribution to VCs to begin with and save a bunch of people from losing their money.

Author: m4lkm4lk
Content: Although you need users to bootstrap the LPs, so I still fall back to why not a time lock. Don't let users dump their coins for at least a year.

Author: m4lkm4lk
Content: Performance metrics would be the best. You want the exchange to succeed. Ultimately exchange volume should be the goal 9/10 and not just LP incentives.

Author: m4lkm4lk
Content: Someone posted instead of using the incentives for LPs use it for marketing and integration. Incentivize traffic on the exchange. Love that idea.

Author: mmoossttaaffaa#6983
Content: UNI in the treasury is owned by UNI holders... it only should be spent to efficiently improve Uniswap or should be distributed to current UNI holders... suggestions like giving it for free to increase UNI distribution are just suggestions to dump on UNI holders the real owners of the treasury

Author: mmoossttaaffaa#6983
Content: UNI holders should never accept not useful proposals that only waste the treasury

Author: mr_po
Content:
> allowing the coin to be dumped and effectively manipulated down on Binance because of low liquidity defeats that purpose. 
@m4lkm4lk If you're a whale and you want to make the price lower, it is easier to do it via Uniswap than via a CEX.

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
> When you stake in PoS, you provide work to improve the network's security and thus increase your share of the network's supply at the expense of the non-stakers
@Po When you stake you are putting up capital that can be taken away from you if you do something bad.

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
> I can't recall a successful protocol that would just distribute new supply towards its holders, this model doesn't make any sense to me - as it theoretically just lowers the price.
@Po The purpose of this isn't to pump UNI price.  It is to basically just a way of burning the UNI without unduly increasing investor/developer share.  It is a way of governance essentially saying, "we aren't going to give this away, lets make that official".

Author: mr_po
Content:
@Micah  it is also akin to saying "we can't do anything useful with these tokens that could drive adoption of the protocol"
Don't you like what Compound is doing with their token? Using it to mitigate the fees so that people have 1% interest on their debts

Author: mr_po
Content: I think that policy is big part of why Compound is successful

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
> I think ineffectual spending is not a major issue at all. Corruption is, but internet space provides more transparency to prevent that
@Po I'm curious to hear why you think that the blockchain being transparent will result in a decrease in corruption that is not completely offset (by a large margin) by the corruption increase from pseudoanonymity.  I also am curious why you think that ineffectual spending is not a major issue, despite all of history suggesting that it is when spending is of other people's money is done by committee.

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
>  it is also akin to saying "we can't do anything useful with these tokens that could drive adoption of the protocol"
@Po Yes effectively.  I'm not yet convinced that we can generate more than $3 worth of value for each UNI spent.  Would be cool to be proven wrong, but history is strongly against that being the case IMO.

Author: mr_po
Content:
> 
> @Po Yes effectively.  I'm not yet convinced that we can generate more than $3 worth of value for each UNI spent.  Would be cool to be proven wrong, but history is strongly against that being the case IMO.
> @Micah when a product gets mass adoption, the returns value invested in getting there get exponential. I'm not sure what history you refer to. There are a lot of examples where the network effects lead to returns that far outweigh the initial investment

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I believe that it is *possible* to get more than $3 of value out of each UNI.  I am unconvinced that *governance* will achieve that.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: If there was a CEO managing the UNI pool then I would definitely advocate for them spending it in ways they see fit (assuming I considered the CEO competent).

Author: sky.cactus
Content:
I guess you could simplify my argument down to:
I consider a plutocratic democracy to be the same as an incredibly incompetent CEO.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: When you have an incompetent CEO but a very competent team, the best thing the CEO can do is nothing.

Author: mr_po
Content:
> @Po I'm curious to hear why you think that the blockchain being transparent will result in a decrease in corruption that is not completely offset (by a large margin) by the corruption increase from pseudoanonymity.  I also am curious why you think that ineffectual spending is not a major issue, despite all of history suggesting that it is when spending is of other people's money is done by committee.
@Micah Again, I'm not sure what part of history is being referred to. There's a field called Institutional Economics that has a completely different premise: that institutions shape human behavior.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The part of history where governance systems have *always* been terribly ineffective at achieving its stated goals.  🙂

Author: mr_po
Content: but some governance systems did a better job than the others, didn't they?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Yes, but all democratic systems have failed pretty miserably on this front IMO.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The ones that are most successful are those that are only faux democratic (essentially, benevolent dictator).

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The root of the problem is that the people who *should* be making decisions are generally not the voters because the voters are not nearly well informed enough to make the decisions that need to be made.

Author: mr_po
Content:
Vitalik Butering wrote a great article recently that distinguishes an important feature most disputes in crypto space have:
 https://vitalik.ca/general/2020/11/08/concave.html

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The reason that CEOs work great is because you have a person who can be decisive and who also spends 40-80 hours a week steeped in "the issues".

Author: sky.cactus
Content: I would be surprised to find out if there is even a single voter who spends 40-80 hours a week thinking about the problems that are being proposed on the UNI forum.  And I guarantee you that the majority of voting power isn't spending that much time thinking about these problems.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Governance may get lucky from time to time when the right solution is also the obvious solution and/or the popular solution, but more often than not the obvious solution/popular solution does not align with the right solution (given some particular set of goals).

Author: mr_po
Content: but it's not a democracy, the Uniswap governance. There are not so many people that need to make right decisions, and they have a lot at stake

Author: mr_po
Content: so it's reasonable to assume that they gain expertise on important matters

Author: mr_po
Content: and they don't have to make popular decisions either

Author: mr_po
Content: at this point the bigger delegates are the "CEO" of Uniswap

Author: mr_po
Content: and I believe they can do better than nothing (nothing being distributing UNI to holders)

unpopular opinion open for discussion:

Do we really need 3B liquidity at the cost of spending UNI from treasury on basically nothing but extra liquiditity?

Author: mr_po
Content: @Boris Stanic An indicator of liquidity not being overincentivized would be if volume correlated with liquidity

Author: mr_po
Content: during the initial mining program volume got lower while liquidity got higher

Author: BOR4#8524
Content: yep that makes sense

Author: mr_po
Content: but there is another thing to consider: the retention effects of liquidity. They probably will fade with time, i.e. the first liquidity mining program gains the most results

Author: mr_po
Content: the first liquidity mining program for Uniswap was done by Sushi

Author: mr_po
Content: USDT/ETH liquidity before: 24 mln, after: 160 mln

Author: mr_po
Content: The volume benchmarks the 1st program: before 18 mln, after 57 mln

Author: mr_po
Content:
Liquidity for the 2nd program: before 160 mln after 200 mln
Volume benchmark: before 57 mln after 38 mln

Author: mr_po
Content:
Liquidity to volume ratios:
before 1st program 1.33
after 1st program 2.80
after 2nd program 5.26

Author: mr_po
Content: I suggest to judge the liquidity mining program's success by the increase in Liquidity to Volume ratio. More appropriately, the equation should involve the amount of money spent on the program

Author: mr_po
Content: It can be judged only retroactively, though, and we need time periods between the programs for that assessment

Author: mr_po
Content: for example, if after the 3rd liquidity mining program we find out that Liquidity to volume ratios stay the same, we could view the retention effects of the stimula as zero

Author: mr_po
Content: these are not exactly correct numbers that I've showed above, they're approximations that illustrate the concept

Author: BOR4#8524
Content: What you are saying makes sense but I think volume is mostly dictated by price action not incentive program

Author: BOR4#8524
Content: maybe

Author: BOR4#8524
Content: I don't know for sure 😛

Author: mr_po
Content: in this model I view volume as the benchmark

Author: mr_po
Content: for example, in august high volume pushed higher liquidity

Author: mr_po
Content: that's why liquidity to volume ratio stayed low

Author: mr_po
Content: another thing to consider as the benchmark is the increase of liquidity to volume ratios on other, non-incentivised pairs

Author: ikjo.
Content: @Micah  Explain this `Uniswap 1 hour TWAP prior to issuing a market sell order`

Author: sky.cactus
Content: In order for a contract to do a market buy or sell on Uniswap, it needs to somehow know the expected price going in, so someone cannot execute a sandwich attack on the swap.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: The easiest way to do this is to get a TWAP for the current price and then go into the trade with an expectation of getting that price, or at least something very close to it.

Author: ikjo.
Content: Thanks .. What is TWAP?

Author: sky.cactus
Content: Time Weighted Average Price

Content: vote delegation can't chain

Author: noahzinsmeister
Content: if a delegates to b, then b delegates to c, c gets delegated b's votes, a's votes remain delegated to b

Content: This would be the biggest let down in history. It has to be possible to add functionality to the governance token without negatively affecting the robustness of the protocol. If UNI was solely added to reward VCs - or, as you say it, fund „development“ - I expect the forks to thrive ...

Author: sky.cactus
Content: There are many people (myself included) who believe that plutocratic governance by vote is not secure or generally a good way to do anything.

Author: notmcd
Content: Functionality != plutocratic governance

Author: sky.cactus
Content: It is pretty rare that a token is actually necessary.  Augur is the canonical example, where REP serves a very clear and distinct purpose.  However, even Augur doesn't have any governance via the token.

Author: sky.cactus
Content: In almost all cases, the addition of a token increases system complexity and generally makes it more expensive/awkward to use.

Author: _allo
Content:
Uniswap 2 can run w/o governance of course, it was coded before governance
Uniswap 3 will be able to run independantly from governance
Governance still controls treasury, still has the same mandate to help uniswap grow.
Tbh it's a good thing Uniswap will continue to run independantly from governance b/c right now governance does almost nothing. the only proposals we had were for a shady retroactive airdrop ( I say this, and I would have received 800 from the first phase of this airdrop if it had been voted). the dev team really **can't** count on governance. the big delegates are just sitting there, doing basically sweet nuthin'. or at least, it's starting to look like it very much.
Also, the purpose of UNI is to get access to fees eventually. But it's only going to be worth it if Uni grows a lot more IMO. Incentives campaigns can help a protocol grow, as you know.

Uniswap has the potential to steal a lot (more) marketshare from CEXes, so I'm pretty sure there are some forces at work behind the scenes. There is a chance that it could explain why governance (= very much controlled by big delegates) has been so stale/uninteresting for now. (Except the nice discussions we have on the governance forum of course). So, to wrap this up, it's a very good thing that Uniswap 3 continues to runs independantly from governance, because it could stay in a deadlock for a long time. That being said, with more active big delegates, governance could also be an asset to the protocol, instead of a deadweight.

PS another reason why big delegates seem to be asleep at the wheel right now could also be that V3 is imminent and they have been told to wait for the release/announcement. Just another guess. We can't really know.

Content:
I think a piece of context is missed out.
The governance doesn't vote on ideas and then ask the devs to develop towards what's been voted.
The proposer proposes the code and once the vote goes through the new code replaces the old code.

Content: https://uniswap.org/blog/year-in-review/

Author: dmitry8749
Content:
**2021 Roadmap:**
Improve automated market making:
The Uniswap team continues to research and develop market leading AMM technology, **making considerable progress on v3.**

V3’s design is driven by a desire to drastically improve the AMM experience for both swappers and LPs, increasing capital efficiency and flexibility while introducing superior execution.

**Explore scaling solutions:**
Scaling solutions present a path to lower latency trading, faster settlement, and cheaper transaction costs.
