Author: aaronp#7699
Content:
**[Temperature Check]** 

The forum wasn't letting me post so thought I'd survey interest here. Trying to see if anyone would want to collaborate on this proposal.

**Proposal**

This post is gauging interest and collaborators in formally proposing that 1% of Uniswap transaction fees go towards RedemptionDAO.

**What is RedemptionDAO?**

27 Million Hectares of protected rainforest are up for auction in the Congo. This is a larger plot of land than all of the National Parks in the USA combined. The bidders are oil companies looking to exploit the land for resources. A grassroots team of over 200 Web3 environmentalists formed RedemptionDAO (redemptionDAO on twitter) to try to raise the funds to win the auction, allowing the continued protection of the land by helping the community earn carbon credits for the avoided deforestation of the peatlands and trees in this area. Donors have already pledged $74,000 but this isn’t enough. Uniswap has the opportunity to show the world that web3 can make positive change in the world. 

**Impact**

Uniswap has the chance to make an impact on the climate crisis, raise awareness about the DAO, and change the public perception of crypto. Additionally, climate crypto is based on Celo (which Uniswap is the recommended DEX for use by the Celo community). Driving liquidity towards climate action would likely increase transaction volume on Uniswap.

Author: simbad.
Content: Hi there, here ´s a question I asked in general Chanel about a governance proposal that already passed, about the moonbeam integration project: the nomad team said on their discord their focus was on the hack recovery process and their involvement in the moonbeam uniswap deployment should be deprecated. They also mentioned that the uni community might want to find another partner for that. Can we have some input from the team/community on that please?

Author: yj_alt
Content:
The moonbeam deployment proposal was co-proposed by Nomad team and Blockchain@Berkeley, with Nomad team meant to do the deployment. Note that the proposal is mainly to provide the Additional Use Grant (as added on-chain) for Nomad to deploy uni-v3 code. Given the current situation, I would imagine that the Additional Use Grant will no longer be exercised, i.e. Nomad will not be working on the uni-v3 moonbeam deployment anymore, as you mentioned.

If the UNI community and governance have appetite to still pursue a uni-v3 moonbeam deployment, the governance process will need to be done again, I would say.

Author: el_primo9474
Content:
Dear Uniswap community, I am Vincent, I hope you are all well. 

I am contacting you to provide our expertise in governance when it comes to the subject of DAOs. 
We are a team of academic researchers, blockchain developers, lawyers, financiers and political scientists who have been working for over 10 years to develop a scientific paradigm for collective decision making, at the intersection of social choice theory, welfare economics, decentralized artificial intelligence, collective intelligence and strategic marketing. 

We have introduced decision rules that offer expressiveness and usability, robustness in the way they analyze information, limited manipulability and scalability. 

The rules are tailor-made: governors can strategically orient the collective decision between performance, equity and consensuality.
We have solved the Condorcet Paradox: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Condorcet_paradox 
which is a 200 year old problem on governance. 

I know that there are many pain points in DAOs and the governance of blockchains protocols nowadays and there are still many challenges to overcome regarding:
- Consensus Mechanism
- Tokenization Mechanism
- Voting Mechanism
- Smart Contract Mechanism.

By working with us you will get assured to get the best recommendations/product which fit your market needs.
Do not hesitate to contact me back if this is of interests to you.

Kind Regards.


Vincent

PS: You will find in attachments a governance consulting proposal with more details regarding what we can offer.

Author: crypto_rachel
Content:
V2 is fixed in contract at the 0.05% for the switch

V3
```As in Uniswap v2, Uniswap v3 has a protocol fee that can be
turned on by UNI governance. In Uniswap v3, UNI governance has
more flexibility in choosing the fraction of swap fees that go to the
protocol, and is able to choose any fraction 1
𝑁 where 4 ≤ 𝑁 ≤ 10,
or 0. This parameter can be set on a per-pool basis```
is a fraction 1/10 thru 1/4
so 10 to 25% of LP fees

Author: anastasia_nakrmili
Content:
Hello, Uniswap community!

We are excited to introduce Holdim (https://twitter.com/Holdim_), an app that we hope will help you follow governance processes more easily and efficiently. Holdim has already received a grant from Uniswap Grants, and as we head into our second Milestone, we want to invite you to participate in the Beta testing of the app. 

Beta testing features include the ability to follow the projects you like or have governance tokens for; in the feed, you will see their governance proposals in the voting stage on Snapshot; all the governance proposals are shown in tl;dr form made by AI. 

We invite you to participate in the small survey and actual testing of our app. In this form (https://forms.gle/B5mHd8P5kCVeK1e89), you can apply to participate and we will have some rewards for you. Thank you for helping us!

Author: Avocadro#0594
Content: Hi Anthony, my survey link keeps getting deleted. Can you check please?

Author: Avocadro#0594
Content:
Hello Uniswap Community!  As part of the mission of our new Foundation to advance research that will improve our ecosystem on behalf of all stakeholders, we are sharing a short survey on governance participation.  The survey is being conducted as a part of pilot study undertaken by researchers from Harvard and Abra, and is aimed in the long run to introduce novel "hive mind" mechanisms that will make proposing, commenting and voting on ideas more effective, enjoyable and inclusive.

https://forms.gle/EHiaSFtS54Xmqbuw7

Author: jam1931
Content:
Hello Uniswap community - Trying to do some market survey from a mature DAO like Uniswap (plz dont ban me 🙏 ). 

What do people think about a partially anonymous forum? Has anyone censored their controversial ideas due to fear of social reprisals? What have you done if your idea goes against the big players in the DAO? Can partial anonymity be a way to start addressing group think?

I understand that social reputation is important in qualifying the ideas but, it also gets in the way of viewing ideas based on its merits. In certain cases, we censor our controversial comments because it goes against the grain of the majority of DAOs and we tend to not point that out because of fear of social reprisal. Again, this may get in the way of having the most effective decision as some ideas are not considered (and that “consensus” is a more of a capitulation than general agreement that we have the best idea.)

I believe that certain topics may require an anon space to assess the ideas by its merits rather than rely too heavily on the social representation (albeit it has an important role in the DAO). 

How do you think anon forums would impact the quality of forum discussions?

Author: crypto_rachel
Content:
You can show me if I'm wrong but 
```
The Infrastructure Bill amends Section 6050I's definition of "cash" to include "digital assets," thereby requiring persons that "receive" greater than $10,000 worth of digital assets in the course of their trade or business to file Form 8300 reports. This new reporting requirement will not take effect until 2024.
```
This is more about taxes than kyc or stolen funds
Taxes they will always go after, and they are getting better at tracking down people, and usually criminals slip up.

I feel pretty confident that the community would be strongly against KYC
We do appreciate your thoughts, and understand your worry as this world is still all wild west, and the controls by the governments are only starting. Yes i'm sure there is more to come but until they can control All of ethereum nodes (which is doubtful) the Uniswap contracts themselves __Will__ remain decentralized and no one can be stopped from using them.  These contracts can be used without any UI or intermediary.

Author: yj_alt
Content:
Liquidity is **pooled**. From a technical perspective, not even sure how you are envisioning "LPs and swappers the ability to swap info when certain thresholds are met"?

Governance is in control of the Uniswap Protocol core smart contracts. Frontend (main one being app.uniswap.org) is open-sourced, and maintained by Uniswap Labs, but not under governance control. If you want to "accommodate LPs and swappers the ability to swap information" at the smart contract level, someone will need to create a whole new AMM for that, nothing UNI governance can do there. And if you are thinking more on the frontend level, see paragraph above.

Overall, I know what you are asking, it's just not a productive/useful thing to ask from Uniswap governance and here, is all. Also, US-based **anything** probably will end up needing to talk to their lawyers/accountants for advice anyways, that's just the situation in the US in general. There are dozens of us not in the US though, and I don't envy the regs there.

Author: yj_alt
Content: Yeah. It is what it is though. Not much governance can do there. See above.

Author: yj_alt
Content: That seems logical and rational to me. But, again, on the other hand there isn't much UNI governance can do to help you remove that risk anyways.

Author: yj_alt
Content: See above re: what UNI governance is in control of. If you are talking about Uniswap Labs (who maintains app.uniswap.org frontend, which is open-sourced code), I think their legal contact is just `legal@uniswap.org`

Author: yj_alt
Content:
> write a little extra code
you are severely underestimating the difficulty of doing what you mentioned 🤣 

As a crude analogy, my personal response to that would be "I am not putting code security at risk because you don't want to move a little bit further away from the US" </s>

Author: PLAY#3825
Content:
MY Proposal
In support of furthering the vision of Multichain Uniswap, proposing that the Uniswap community vote to authorize the deployment of Uniswap bridge. We hope this proposal will serve as an example to create a generalizable, trust-minimized approach to cross-chain deployments, with the goal of supporting a multichain Uniswap ecosystem.

As implied in the name, bridges allow one to easily migrate tokens from one chain to another. 

For example converting from Ethereum to Arbitrum, Optimism, Polygon, Celo you will need to have some ETH in your Ethereum wallet to cover gas fees when converting. Similarly user should be able to migrate from the different chains supported by Uniswap

For this we would be creating separate tab in the home page of Uniswap.

Example use case
To switch between Ethereum and Arbitrum:
Click on the "Bridge" tab, and select "Arbitrum Bridge":

This will take you to the Arbitrum Token Bridge, where you can connect your wallet and "deposit/withdraw" tokens to and from the Arbitrum network.

Conclusion
Uniswap as community together we can serve as the foundation for the proliferation of natural capital assets across Web3. We believe that the vision to advance decentralization of financial services. Thank you for your consideration and we welcome questions and suggestions.

Author: jam1931
Content:
Hey Uniswap community - we are looking for people and DAOs to pilot test our MVP Anon forum. We want to build a decentralized and anonymous platform to facilitate meaningful and insightful discourse that further facilitates DAOs to act more effectively and efficiently. First things first, we have built an anonymous forum (via semaphore) and we are collecting people to try it out 🙂 

We are bringing privacy to the forums because we believe anonymity can bring about change in the group think problem that DAOs are facing. Anonymity brings people down to a horizontal organization and we believe this can partly tackle the problem! We have a couple of other iterations in mind but would love some feedback! 

Please reply here or DMs are welcome too!

1. We are looking for proposer who wants to (re-)write their proposals on our forum to see if we can get any feedback that wasnt in the original forum or constructive feedback 
2. OR we can get a *controversial* proposal from the past (or on-going) to see if we can get any other feedback that wasnt received before and the sentiment of the people are different.

Author: leilyof
Content: Hi, I am kinda new to all this web3 ecosystem. I am trying to gain some more information about how uniswap governance actually works. I know that UNI community treasury is managed through voting and proposals. I wanted to know if uniswap governance can be considered a multisig governance too. Are the funds in the treasury in a multisignature wallet controlled by a group of signers?  I know that community treasury funds are allocated using auto-transactions and smart contracts based on proposals. Is this the case for UNI grant projects or are there some people who have direct access to the funds and allocate them to applicants?

Author: getty
Content: Uniswap uses a traditional on-chain governance system developed by the Compound community called Governor Bravo. The protocol's assets are kept in a Timelock contract which is controlled by the governance contract. The protocol's UNI treasury is held in the timelock and UNI token holders can make proposals on the governor contract which can result in moving UNI tokens in the treasury if the sufficient number of votes are cast.

Author: getty
Content: https://docs.uniswap.org/concepts/governance/overview

Author: getty
Content: the docs could use a bit of a refresh but generally are decent

Author: leilyof
Content: Thank you🙏

Author: sato#7228
Content:
gm gm Unicorns! 
We want to share with you an analysis on Uniswap Stickiness that we did at Almanak.
**TL;DR**: 
- And because of the occurrence of triangular inter-pool trading within Uniswap pools, measuring and understanding stickiness is challenging.

- Even though we could still imply it from the other pools (used for triangular spillovers) change in activity post-switch vs historical levels, it’s difficult to disentangle what share of that activity would be resulting from which pool among the three activated pools.

- Stickiness (of trading and liquidity) is very pool-specific.

- From our analysis ETH-DAI 0.05% and ETH-USDC 1% would not be too impacted by this side effect. The former a bit more than the latter due to whale behaviour.

- However ETH-USDT 0.3% seems more prone, with #jit playing a role on liquidity and #curve on trading volume.

Overall outcome is clearly agent-driven so the experimentation will benefit from incorporating behavioural analysis through simulation.
https://almanak-co.medium.com/glued-to-the-exchange-how-sticky-is-the-user-base-of-uniswap-pools-2238b6be8bf4

1) Is there a formal onboarding/offboarding process?

3) Is there a dedicated person or team assigned to the DAO’s treasury?
4) are delegates compensated?

Thanks so much for taking the time to help out!

Author: 0xbuzzlightyear
Content:
Hello everyone, would appreciate it very much if anyone could give their opinion on this. Please have a look into this RFC and feel free to ask any questions by @ me here or directly in the governance forum.
Here is the thesis for those who don't want to open the link:
**Thesis:**

This proposal seeks to deploy a 1bp fee tier for UniswapV3 on Arbitrum. This will allow users to trade with lower fees, making it more accessible and competitive with other decentralized exchanges.

Since the launch on mainnet, there seems to be enough data to prove the effectiveness of a 1bp fee tier in increasing swap volume for Uniswap.

Currently, the Uniswap 1bp fee tier is live on the mainnet, Optimism and Polygon. Based on data and the impact it’ll have on the trading volumes, there’s no reason for it not to exist for Arbitrum.

https://gov.uniswap.org/t/rfc-enable-a-1bp-fee-tier-for-uniswapv3-on-arbitrum/20116

Author: BOR4#8524
Content:
@awbvious I pinged proposers but couldn't get any insight. It seems everyone is busy with selecting the bridge for BSC deployment.

Regarding deploying Uniswap on different chains and L2 solutions. I agree, some of the deployments are happening on chains that traded off decentralization for scaling/speed and fees. It seems like Uniswap governance doesn't think that those are deal breakers and is willing to deploy on these solutions as well.

With that said, making Uniswap available on these solutions doesn't affect in any way Uniswap on Ethereum L1 or rollup scaling solutions. It is not that we are shutting down Ethereum deployment and are completely switching to BSC. We are just giving people option to choose. And, in my opinion, when you look at it that way there is no reason for Uniswap not to be present on those chains as well. Furthermore, some of these solutions might adopt POS and go decentralized in the future and then we might regret not having first mover advantage.

Data backs that also. We have Celo deployment but people don't think it is best place for them. That is why adoption on it is lacking. We just gave people option to choose, nobody is making people switch from solutions they feel comfortable interacting with to go to these new solutions.

Regarding whales swinging votes in Uniswap governance. Yes, whales have big influence in Uniswap governance but over time their influence should became less and less dominant. As more people get into UNI token less and less voting power will be in hands of whales and in the future we might see less whale domination in voting.

Author: awbvious
Content: Specifically regarding " It is not that we are shutting down Ethereum deployment and are completely switching to BSC."  I realized that, but you should reach out to cointelegraph for a correction: https://cointelegraph.com/news/uniswap-holders-ditch-ethereum-for-bnb-pos-chain-to-deploy-v3-protocol .  I was most surprised that someone at cointelegraph even /thought/ that Uniswap was "ditching" Ethereum, or that such an error got past their editorial staff.  Someone should reach out for a retraction/correction.  "As more people get into UNI token"--but there's a fundamental logic block to that...  Right now, 8 UNI holders can sway a vote.  8.  Why would any regular person think they can compete with that?  In, say, most IRL political voting, it's one vote per person.  If you knew your vote was worth one millionth of, say, the top 8 richest people in the land, it would be pretty discouraging.  Now, if UNI was profit-sharing like some others out there that, you know, recently surpassed Uniswap in trading volume (something that would be unheard of until recently), maybe you'd get more people out there interested in UNI, but right now?  If anything I see /less/ interest in UNI as time goes on, and more in other decentralized exchanges that give profit sharing and other unique features like leverage.  Of course, that's tricky, Uniswap has already had to censor its front end for regulators/authorities, start doing leverage or profit sharing... yeah...  But, put in quadratic voting or something like that, and I doubt regulators would care.  In fact I suspect it would /help/ Uniswap in the eyes of regulators.  Because if power is in the hands of 8 individuals it looks more like "expectation of profit based on the efforts of others," while more power to more people means more any expectations would be in the efforts of one's self--and that's not even looking at anti-trust/monopoly concerns.

Author: awbvious
Content: That's perhaps the only reason I can see those UNI whales being willing to give up some of their power.  It could keep regulators at bay.  Compromise a little power or else lose it all.  It may be needed for self-preservation.  Now then, what is the real danger of Uniswap being on a chain that can be completely manipulated?  Let's say the most alarming interpretation of that datafinnovation article is true, that Binance Beacon chain can basically be rewritten at will, and thus can rewrite BSC at will.  Let's just simplify it and say CZ has a magic button that can do anything he wants to any transaction that happens at BSC and CZ actually wants to use it.  Yeah, what is the worst case?  I don't know.   He takes all the liquidity on their and puts it in his own account?  I mean all the governance voting still happens on Ethereum I assume (Binance, of course, is one of the biggest holders of UNI--but I don't think the use it to vote--yet [unlikely ever]).  I mean, that should be an amendment too, you should not be allowed to vote on anything you have a really strong financial incentive, like Andreessen Horowitz should not have been allowed to vote for Celo, and anything Binance/CZ/etc has should not be allowed to vote for BSC.  I am curious about the doomsday scenarios, and no one's talking about them.  Maybe because there are none.  But security often comes up in conversations regarding Uniswap deployments, so I'd imagine they should come up for going to BSC as well.

Author: awbvious
Content: Here's another thing to think about.  Solana.  Or "Sam's coin" as they called it, since he had so much of it and was so deep into so many of the dapps.  FTX imploded and it hurt Solana, which had always had issues with it being centralized.  As a thought experiment...  What would have happened to Uniswap if it was on Solana?  And, you know, it is kind of applicable that Serum had a secret backdoor with FTX that ultimately lead developers to fork.  Isn't that kind of what exists with Beacon Chain?  A secret backdoor?  If Binance implodes, and starts to take BSC, will it have to fork because of this backdoor?  What happens to uniswap then?  and so on and so forth.  I don't know.  Let's talk doomsday, though, I say.

Author: awbvious
Content: Wait...  https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2023/01/31/wormhole-wins-vote-to-be-uniswaps-designated-bridge-to-bnb-chain/  "The Wormhole bridge will eventually be used to give Uniswap v3 users on BNB Chain the ability to participate in the Uniswap DAO’s Ethereum-based governance process."  So, I know UNI is already bridged to BSC..."  Is there more to this?  The voting is still done ON ethereum right?  If not, then yeah, that's a big deal.  Am I really worried about CZ?  No.  Am I worried that they could be sloppy and someone in Binance who "fixes the hashes" or whatever it is, either themselves or after that person has being spearphished by lazarus or something, will be a security issue?  Yeah, I am.  And if Binance--which seems too big to fail (but that's not stopped others before)--DOES start crumbling... or more likely death spiraling if that happened... well, I definitely think we can look at FTX for some guidance on that, and how someone was able to steal some $600 million in tokens in the confusion.  Right now, UNI is bridged to BSC, but after Wormhole (assuming it's the bridge of choice--and let's hope Jump has some more in the seat cushions if there's another issue--though I bet contagion has hit them more than they've ever let on), would that mean LOTS more UNI is bridged?  What exactly is going to happen?

Author: ohadbachner
Content: Hi there! A proposal decision being voted on Ethereum can be updated on other chains through cross-chain communication bridges. These bridges allow for the transfer of information and assets between different blockchain networks. The update can either be done manually or through automated means, depending on the implementation of the bridge.

Author: awbvious
Content: Another thing to consider is voting for a non-whale is a lot of risk for a lot less (potential) benefit.  Once there's a way to vote on a Dapp, there's likely not going to be any airdrops to reward engagement.  Because the way to vote on the Dapp is very likely because of the one and only airdrop the Dapp will ever have: namely an airdrop of a governance token.  There's been moments of bandying about of another Uniswap drop, and I doubt that will ever happen (see previous point about power consolidation and desire for status quo by those in power).   So, your vote is unlikely to matter, and you're unlikely to get an airdrop.  Now, what kind of risk is there?  Look at Ooki (originally known as BZeroX or bZx).  Something very few people have mentioned (but myself, in fact I don't know of anyone else mentioning it / aware of it), is that the CFTC went after anyone who voted on an Ooki proposals, ostensibly as a way to "go after" the DAO and discourage devs who think they can "hide behind" a DAO.  But that's ridiculous a) because they didn't just go after votes that are specifically related to the actions Ooki was (is?) taking that they dislike (leverage without KYC and presumably even then only for accredited individuals) and b) you'd have to be ridiculously wealthy in Ooki/BZRX tokens to even be able to propose--like $100k in either to be able to propose.  They should have only gone after at least those who voted and fit b, and very possibly both a and b (if anyone at all, because that assumes a handful of devs can afford or should afford to maintain the necessary programs for compliance for regulation that isn't even defined AND the underlying regulation may just be gatekeeping for rich people who are just assumed to be better investors)... but I'm digressing.  Point is, tons of risk in voting now.  And little potential reward.  Add in lack of fair representation.  Doesn't look good for DAOs/governance.

Author: awbvious
Content: ooh, good point.  hmm...  One possible solution could be the concept of soulbound tokens, another thing that Vitalik Buterin has talked about.  But I just had a thought.  Maybe include something like the slashing that occurs to bad-faith validators in Proof of Staking, but have it for voting who do it bad-faith voting like sybil voting.  In many ways, it's a similar thing.  You don't have to know how to detect sybillism.   You just have to make the punishment a big enough deterrent that it's not worth it to attempt.  Slashing wouldn't work on everyone, but I think it absolutely work on someone like a16z.  Their reputation is too important to them to risk it by manipulating governance on any one vote or any one dapp.  I think it would work--it wouldn't be reinventing the wheel, it would be using a wheel that's working really well already on PoS, but putting it on a different type of vehicle.  Eventually, solutions will come around to detect sybillism--account reputation, using AI to see patterns between connections of accounts and voting history (thankfully both on chain, making it easier), a process for accusing voters and voters having a process for defending themselves--but in the meantime slashing could be turned on immediately with quadratic voting and that should alone contain the threat.  Again, specifically with regards to a16z, which is not some anonymous, shadowy group, but an entity that would very much not want to be caught in the court of public opinion having been slashed for sybillism.

Author: awbvious
Content: So.  Not sure if everyone noticed this: https://cointelegraph.com/news/jump-crypto-unveils-critical-vulnerability-on-binance-s-bnb-chain .  https://jumpcrypto.com/helping-secure-bnb-chain-through-responsible-disclosure/ .  I started getting involved in this governance channel for Uniswap because I wanted to get some insight on this: https://discord.com/channels/597638925346930701/755969053280960533/1067150274558439515 .  https://datafinnovation.medium.com/bnb-beacon-chain-not-a-blockchain-3230dda7172c .  No one basically engaged with me on that issue.  I was beginning to worry I was being the proverbial "Chicken Little."  It would be nice to know if my prodding helped in anyway in this, but it's aso very likely Jump Crypto had independently heard about this datafinnovation post and/or point within--namely that BSC and the Binance Beacon Chain have a weird dependency and that Binance Beacon Chain has very likely vulnerabilities in the way it is a custom fork of Cosmos.  It makes perfect sense that Jump Crypto then investigated, and specifically now, because (for those that don't know) Jump Crypto bailed out Wormhole.  https://decrypt.co/92709/jump-crypto-wormhole-defi .  Just as a16z clearly tries to protect it's own investments, so does Jump Crypto.  Wormhole and Solana are both big investments, and a massive mint exploit cost them dearly in bailout, but likely worse if they hadn't bailed out Wormhole.  Jump Crypto is probably even more invested in Wormhole now, and probably a lot of BSC.  So Jump Crypto did the sensible thing to investigate, if Beacon is a fork of Cosmos, compare the custom code to the Cosmos code.  And found out it could cause the same issue: a massive mint exploit.  There is still worry, though, as nothing in the Jump Crypto piece talks about about the other major issue: That Binance can apparently just fix/change hashes as desired on Beacon Chain.  But, suffice to say, don't feel so "Chicken Little" now.

Author: awbvious
Content: By the way, I think I've discovered a great way to find and fix bugs on your chain: Deploy Uniswap.  Seems they get found always around the time of Uniswap joining the chain.  Polygon voted in / deployed to Uniswap, Decemember 22, 2021: https://www.coindesk.com/markets/2021/12/22/uniswap-launches-on-polygon-driving-matic-to-all-time-highs/ .  Polygon major bug found and fixed, December 29, 2021: https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2021/12/29/polygon-discloses-patched-exploit-that-put-9b-matic-at-risk/ .  Celo voted in for Uniswap, March 11, 2022:  https://cointelegraph.com/news/celo-foundation-proposes-to-deploy-uniswap-v3-on-its-native-blockchain .   Celo major bug found and fixed, February 3, 2022: https://forum.celo.org/t/on-baklava-stall-security-vulnerability-fixed-on-1-5-2/2776 .  Binance vote in for Uniswap, February 10, 2023: https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2023/02/10/uniswap-vote-on-bnb-deployment-ends-with-silicon-valleys-a16z-on-losing-side/ .  Binance major bug found and fixed, February 11, 2023: https://cointelegraph.com/news/jump-crypto-unveils-critical-vulnerability-on-binance-s-bnb-chain  .  Guys, it's pretty clear, don't waste money on doing your own testing.  Just get Uniswap deployed on your chain.

Author: slagathorthemammothking
Content:
Hello, I am Peter from Origin Protocol. In 2020 we released the first stablecoin that earns a yield while sitting in your wallet, the Origin Dollar (OUSD). The yield is generated by tapping into multiple protocols such as Aave, Compound, Morpho, and Curve. As of February 3rd, Origin governance ratified a proposal to have a Uniswap V3 strategy for yield: https://snapshot.org/#/ousdgov.eth/proposal/0xe76cf1d102c4c119e2cef6584731cc228c9793c44187b5dcfab1a75fd038f55f 
The TLDR from this ratification is that Origin will soon be depositing millions of dollars into Uniswap, indefinitely. 

The problem however, is that the two tokens we need to utilize this strategy, OUSD and OGV, are both currently blocked with a warning sign on the platform (see screenshot). We have reached out to support@uniswap.org, opened multiple support tickets, and reached out to @Anthony 🦄 // Community Manager, to remove this warning but are still seeing it on the Uniswap V3 dex. At this point a governance proposal to the Uniswap DAO may be the only feasible way to remove this warning. 

Have there been any proposals to remove the warning sign in the past? Or is there a template somewhere for proposals of this nature? We’re not just minting assets that might generate trading fees, we’re going to be depositing millions of dollars here.

Author: maximiliendyor
Content: @Anthony 🦄 // Community Manager hello 🙂 would you please let me know who could help me on that question ? Thanks 😊

Author: 0xbright
Content:
Hello Uniswap Community! 

DAO Realm is a new product committed to sharing all the latest updates on grants, proposals, and relevant news in the DAO ecosystem. We took to Twitter to express our unwavering support for the recent request for proposals concerning Arb token distribution.

At DAO Realm, our ultimate aim is to contribute to the success and prosperity of Uniswap. We understand the significance of this initiative, and we are eagerly anticipating the best outcome for the community—one that not only benefits Uniswap but also brings substantial value to the ~4.4 million tokens received.

Content:
Dear  Uniswap

I hope this message finds you well. My name is Fred , and I represent a passionate community of blockchain enthusiasts who firmly believe in the transformative potential of decentralized finance (DeFi). I am reaching out to you today to explore a mutually beneficial collaboration that could revolutionize the DeFi landscape.

As you may be aware, the recent years have witnessed a remarkable rise in the popularity of decentralized finance, with numerous innovative protocols offering a diverse range of financial services. However, despite this progress, we believe that there is a significant untapped opportunity to integrate Satoshi Chain into the existing DeFi ecosystem, taking it to new heights of efficiency, security, and scalability.

Satoshi Chain, named in honor of the enigmatic creator of Bitcoin, seeks to build upon the foundations laid by Bitcoin and further enhance the capabilities of DeFi protocols. By incorporating Satoshi Chain into your existing infrastructure, your DeFi protocol can benefit from its unique features, including:

Author: fav_truffe
Content:
Hey Uniswap frens! This is Fav from Hats Finance, the most cost-efficient crowd audit competition and on-chain bug bounty protocol. I have a proposal to carry out a crowd audit competition for UniswapX on Hats protocol, who can i talk to regarding a potential partnership?

Very briefly, our crowd audit competition product is based on payment for results but not for the efforts (as in the case of traditional auditing). Accordingly, if your auditors did a good job and no vulnerabilities are found in the contest, there will not be any sort of payment (including fees as well). Or if only low vulnerability issues are found, Uniswap will only pay the amount allocated for low severity, etc.

Author: crypto_rachel
Content: Please reach out to contact@uniswap.org
